ARTICLE IV. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 14-100. - Purpose. 
The intent of the city council in enacting this article is to regulate certain types of businesses, including, but not limited to, adult entertainment establishments, to the end that the many types of criminal activities frequently engendered by such businesses and the adverse effect on property values, on the public health, safety, and welfare of the city, on its citizens and property, and on the character of its neighborhoods and development will be curtailed. This ordinance is not intended as a de facto prohibition of legally protected forms of expression. Instead, this article is intended to represent a balancing of competing interests: reduced criminal activity and protection of neighborhoods and development through the regulation of adult entertainment establishments versus any legally protected rights of adult entertainment establishments and their patrons. This article is not intended to allow or license any business, establishment, or activity which would otherwise be unlawful. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-101. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
Adult bookstore means an establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, books, printed material, magazines, or other periodicals which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter which depicts, describes, or in any way relates to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, or an establishment with a segment or section of the store, comprising five percent of its total floor space, which is devoted to the sale or display of such material, or an establishment with five percent of its net sales consisting of printed material which is distinguished or characterized by its emphasis on matter which depicts, describes, or relates to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult business means any establishment which is either expressly specified in this article, or which is other than those expressly specified in this article, where employees or patrols expose specified anatomical areas or engage in specified sexual activities, or which offers its patrons a service or entertainment of any type which is characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, discussing, or relating in any way to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult dancing establishment means any business or establishment where employees or dancers display or expose specified anatomical areas to others, or any establishment which features live performances by entertainers or employees where such performances are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult entertainment establishment means any adult theater, adult bookstore, adult dancing establishment, adult video store, erotic dance establishment or escort service which conducts business in the city. No adult entertainment establishment shall conduct business in the city without first having obtained a license as set forth in this article. 
Adult theater means any establishment which consists of an enclosed building, or a portion or part of an enclosed building, used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
Adult video store means an establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, videotapes or movies, or other reproductions, whether for sale or for rent, which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating in any way to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, or any establishment with a segment or section, comprising five percent or more of its total floor space, which is devoted to the sale or display of such material or which derives more than five percent of its net sales from videos which are characterized or distinguished by their emphasis on matter which depicts, describes, or relates in any way to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Employee means a person who works or performs in an adult entertainment establishment, irrespective of whether such person is paid a salary or wage. 
Erotic dance establishment means a nightclub, theater, cafe or other establishment which offers live performances by topless and/or bottomless dancers, go-go dancers, strippers or similar entertainers, where such performances are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Escort bureau means any business, person, or agency who, for a fee, commission, hire, reward, or profit furnishes or offers to furnish the names of persons, or who introduces, furnishes, or arranges for persons who may accompany other persons to or about social affairs, entertainments, or places of amusement, or who may consort with others about any place of public resort or within any private quarters. 
Good moral character means a person is of good moral character according to this chapter if that person has not been convicted of any felony or any nonfelony involving moral turpitude in the past five years. The city may also take into account such other factors as are necessary to determine the good moral character of the applicant or employee. For the purposes of this definition, conviction shall include pleas of nolo contendre or bond forfeiture when charged with either a felony, or a nonfelony involving moral turpitude. 
Minor means any person who has not attained the age of 18 years of age. 
Specified anatomical areas means acts, conduct or appearances which include any of the following: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region, buttock, or female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; or 
(2)  Human male genitalia in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
Specified sexual activities means acts, conduct or appearances which include any of the following: 
(1)  Actual or simulated sexual intercourse, oral copulation, anal intercourse, oral anal copulation, bestiality, direct physical stimulation or unclothed genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship including sadomasochistic abuse, or the use of excretory functions in the context of a sexual relationship, and any of the following sexually oriented acts or conduct: anilingus, buggery, coprophagy, coprophilia, cunnilingus, fellation, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, lesbianism, zooerastia; or 
(2)  Clearly depicted human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation, arousal, or tumescence; or 
(3)  Use of human or animal ejaculation, sodomy, oral copulation, coitus, or masturbation; or 
(4)  Fondling or touching of nude human genitals, pubic regions, buttocks, or female breast; or 
(5)  Masochism, erotic or sexually oriented torture, beating or the infliction of pain; or 
(6)  Erotic or lewd touching, fondling, or other sexually oriented contact with an animal by a human being; or 
(7)  Human excretion, urination, menstruation, vaginal or anal irrigation. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Secs. 14-102—14-104. - Reserved. 
Sec. 14-105. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of an offense, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-3 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Douglasville. Each such person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any violation of any provision of this section is committed, continued or permitted by such person. 
(b)  Any adult entertainment establishment, adult business, escort bureau, adult theater, erotic dance establishment or adult video store operated, conducted, or maintained contrary to the provisions of this ordinance shall be and is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. In addition to any other penalties or remedies provided in this article, the city may commence an action or actions to enjoin, abate, or remove any violations of the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  Any violation of the provisions of this article shall be considered due cause for the suspension or revocation of any licenses issued by the city to the offending party. Such revocation or suspension shall occur by way of a hearing before the city council as provided by this article. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-106. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, association, partnership, corporation, or other business entity to engage in, operate, conduct, or carry on in or upon any premises an adult entertainment establishment, adult business, escort bureau, adult or erotic dance establishment, adult theater or adult video store without first having complied with the provisions of this ordinance, or without a currently valid license issued by the city for the operation of an adult entertainment establishment. No license issued hereunder shall condone or make legal any activity thereunder if the same is deemed illegal or unlawful under the laws of the State of Georgia or the United States or under any other ordinance, rule, or regulation of Douglas County. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-107. - Admission of minors unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, licensee, or other adult entertainment establishment, adult business, adult or erotic dance establishment, adult theater, escort bureau, or adult video store to admit or permit the admission of minors into the premises of their adult business or adult entertainment establishment, or to allow a minor to remain within a licensed or unlicensed premises of such a business or establishment. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-108. - Erotic and adult dance establishment regulations. 
(a)  No person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity shall advertise or cause to be advertised an erotic or adult dance establishment without a valid adult entertainment license issued pursuant to this article. 
(b)  An erotic or adult dance establishment shall maintain and retain for a period of two years the names, addresses and ages of all persons employed as dancers. 
(c)  No adult entertainment establishment shall employ or contract with as a dancer any person under the age of 18 years or a person not licensed pursuant to this article. 
(d)  No person under the age of 18 years shall be admitted to an adult entertainment establishment. 
(e)  An erotic or adult dance establishment may be open only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m. Monday through Friday, and on Saturday from 9:00 a.m. through 1:00 a.m. Erotic and adult dance establishments shall not be open for business on Christmas Day. 
(f)  No erotic or adult dance establishment shall serve, sell, distribute or suffer the consumption or possession of any alcoholic beverage upon the premises of the licensee. 
(g)  All dancers shall perform only on a platform or stage intended for such purpose which is raised two feet or more from the level of the remainder of the floor. 
(h)  No dancer shall perform closer than ten feet from any patron. 
(i)  No dancer shall solicit any pay, tip or gratuity from any patron; no patron shall directly pay, give or extend any pay, tip or gratuity to any dancer. 
(j)  All areas of an erotic dance establishment shall be fully lighted at all times that patrons are present, entertainment is being provided or erotic dancers are performing. Full lighting as used in this article shall mean illumination equal to at least ten foot-candles per square foot at or above 48 inches from the floor. 
(k)  The violation of any provision of this section by any erotic dancer, licensee or employee at any licensed premises shall constitute grounds for the revocation, suspension or probation of any adult entertainment license issued in regard to the licensed premises. The holder of any license sought to be revoked or suspended shall have the right to a hearing before the city council. The hearing shall be at a regular or special meeting of the city council. The city clerk shall give the holder of the license at least seven days prior written notice of such hearing, and such notice shall state the grounds upon which the license is sought to be revoked or suspended. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-109. - Location business requirements. 
No adult entertainment establishment, adult business, adult or erotic dance establishment, escort bureau, adult theater or adult video store shall be located within the following distance and measurement as defined and stated herein: 
(1)  Within 600 feet of any property zoned residential; 
(2)  Within 1,000 feet of a church, school, library, civic center, public park, hospital, community club or governmental building; 
(3)  Within 1,000 feet of any establishment or business regulated or defined hereunder; 
(4)  Within 1,000 feet of an establishment selling alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption; 
(5)  On less than two acres of land having at least 100 feet to frontage upon a public road; 
(6)  All distances referred to in this section shall be measured from property line to property line. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-110. - Employees. 
(a)  Employees of adult entertainment establishments, adult businesses, escort bureaus, adult or erotic dance establishments, adult theaters and adult video stores shall be not less than 18 years of age, and shall be of good moral character as defined in this article. 
(b)  Before any person may work at an adult entertainment establishment, such person must file a notice with the finance director of such intended employment on forms supplied by the finance director and shall receive approval of such employment from the finance director. A nonrefundable fee of $25.00 to partially defray the cost of the investigation and background check shall accompany the notice of intended employment. The prospective employee shall supply such information as required by the finance director, including a set of fingerprints upon forms approved by the city police department. After investigation of the proposed employee and upon approval, the finance director shall cause to be issued to the employee an employee identification card and the employee may begin working on the licensed premises. The employee identification card shall expire upon said person's birthday and be renewable annually thereafter. If approval is denied, the prospective employee may, within ten days of said denial, make written notice of appeal of such decision to the city council pursuant to the procedures set forth in section 14-120 of this article. 
(c)  Violations of the provisions of this article, the ordinances of the city, or the laws of the State of Georgia may subject an employee to suspension or revocation of his license for employment. Any employee whose license and identification card is suspended or revoked shall have the right to a hearing before the city council. 
(d)  For the purposes of this article, independent contractors shall be considered as employees and shall be licensed as employees, regardless of the business relationship with the owner or licensee of any adult entertainment establishment. 
(e)  It shall be the duty of all licensees of an adult entertainment establishment, adult business, adult or erotic dance establishments, adult theaters, escort bureaus, or adult video store to file with the Douglasville Police Department the names of all employees with their home addresses and home telephone numbers and places of employment. Changes in the list of employees must be filed with the Douglasville Police Department within seven from the date of any such changes. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93; Ord. No. O-2013-53, § 5, 12-16-13) 
Secs. 14-111—14-114. - Reserved. 
Sec. 14-115. - Application for adult entertainment establishment license. 
(a)  Any person, association, partnership or corporation desiring to obtain a permit to operate, engage in, conduct or carry on any adult entertainment establishment shall make application to the finance director upon forms supplied by the finance director. At the time of application, a nonrefundable fee, established by resolution of the city council, shall be paid to the finance director to defray, in part, the cost of investigation and report required by this article. 
(b)  The application for a license does not authorize the engaging in, operation of, or conduct of any adult entertainment establishment. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93; Ord. No. O-2013-53, § 6, 12-16-13) 
Sec. 14-116. - Application contents. 
Each application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The true full name and any other names used by the applicant; 
(2)  The present address and telephone number of the applicant; 
(3)  The previous addresses of the applicant, if any, for a period of five years immediately prior to the date of application and the dates of residence at each; 
(4)  Acceptable evidence that the applicant is at least 21 years of age; 
(5)  Two photographs of the applicant at least two inches by two inches taken with the preceding six months; 
(6)  The business, occupation or employment history of the applicant for the five years immediately preceding the date of application. If the applicant is a partnership or corporation, the business, occupation and employment records of all partners, directors and officers of such corporation and all shareholders holding more than five percent of the shares of corporate stock outstanding shall be furnished; 
(7)  The business license history of the applicant and whether such applicant, director, officer of a corporation, partner, or shareholder holding five percent of the outstanding stock has previously held a permit or license for adult entertainment, and, if so, whether such previous license had ever been suspended or revoked and the reasons therefor; 
(8)  All criminal convictions, including ordinance violations, exclusive of traffic violations, to include dates and places of conviction. 
(9)  If the applicant is a corporation, a copy of the articles of incorporation and the certificate of incorporation, together with the names and addresses of all officers and directors, and the names and addresses of all stockholders holding more than five percent of the outstanding stock of the corporation. If the applicant is a partnership, the applicant shall set forth the names, addresses, and dates of birth of the partners, including limited partners. If the applicant is a limited partnership, it shall furnish a copy of its certificate of limited partnership filed with the clerk of superior court. If one or more of the partners is a corporation, the provisions of this article pertaining to corporations shall apply. An applicant which is a corporation or partnership shall designate one of its officers or general partners to act as its responsible managing officer. Such designated person shall complete and sign all applications forms required of an individual applicant under this article, but only one application fee shall be charged; 
(10)  The name and address of the owner or lessor of the property upon which the business is to be conducted and a copy of the lease or rental agreement; 
(11)  The age and date of birth of the applicant, of any partners, or of any and all officers, directors and stockholders of more than five percent of the outstanding stock of the corporation if the applicant is a corporation; 
(12)  If the applicant, any partners or any of the officers, directors or stockholders of more than five percent of the outstanding stock of the corporation have ever been convicted of any felony, or of any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, in the preceding five years and, if so, a complete description of such crime, including dates of violation, dates of conviction, jurisdiction and disposition, including any fine or sentence imposed. 
(13)  Individual applicants shall furnish fingerprints upon forms approved by the Douglasville Police Department; 
(14)  If the applicant is doing business under a trade name, a copy of the trade name properly recorded; 
(15)  The address of the premises to be licensed; 
(16)  A plat by a surveyor or engineer licensed by the State of Georgia, showing the location of the proposed premises in relation to the surrounding zoning and the proximity of the premises to any nearby church, school, public park, governmental building or other business regulated under this article or any nearby business licensed to sell alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption. 
(17)  Each application for an adult entertainment license shall be verified and acknowledged under oath to be true and correct by: 
a.  If the applicant is an individual, the individual; 
b.  If the applicant is a partnership, by a general partner or managing partner; 
c.  If the applicant is a corporation, by its president or chief executive officer. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-117. - Application; investigation; grant of license. 
The city shall have 30 days to investigate the application and the background of applicant. Upon completion of the investigation, the city clerk shall cause the matter to be placed upon the agenda of the next regularly scheduled council meeting for action by the city council. The city council may grant the license if it finds: 
(1)  All required fees have been paid; there are no unpaid ad valorem taxes owed re the property upon which the proposed location is to be located; and the applicant owes no unpaid ad valorem taxes to the City of Douglasville; 
(2)  The application conforms in all respects to the provisions of this article; 
(3)  The applicant has not knowingly made a material misrepresentation in the application; 
(4)  The applicant, if an individual, or any of the stockholders of the corporation, officers or directors, if the applicant is a corporation, or any of the partners, if the applicant is a partnership, has not been convicted of a felony or of any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
(5)  The applicant, if an individual, or any of the stockholders of the corporation, officers or directors, if the applicant is a corporation, or any of the partners, if the applicant is a partnership, has not had a prior permit or license for adult entertainment revoked or suspended by any governmental body; 
(6)  The building and location of the proposed adult entertainment establishment is in compliance with all applicable laws or ordinances, including health, zoning, prohibited distances and fire and safety codes; 
(7)  The applicant is at least twenty one (21) years of age; 
(8)  That on the date the business for which a license is sought commences business, and at all times thereafter, there will be a responsible person on the premises to act as manager at all times during which the business is open; 
(9)  That the proposed location is not within the prohibited distance as set forth in this article from any church, school, library, governmental building, residential property, or business regulated under this article. 
(10)  That the grant of such license will not cause a violation of this article or of any other law, ordinance or regulation of the city or the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-118. - Persons prohibited as licensees. 
(a)  No license provided by this article shall be issued to or held by: 
(1)  An applicant who has not paid all fees and taxes for a business at the proposed location; 
(2)  Any person not of good moral character as defined in this article; 
(3)  Any corporation, any of whose officers, directors or stockholders holding more than five percent of the outstanding issued shares of the corporation, is not of moral character as defined in this article; 
(4)  Any partnership or association, any of whose partners are not of good moral character as defined in this article. 
(b)  Should there be a sufficient number of current licenses to meet the needs and desires of the inhabitants of the city, no new licenses shall issue. In determining the needs and desires of the inhabitants, the standard of review shall be that the market is virtually unrestrained as set forth in Young v. American Mini Theaters, Inc. (427 U.S. 50, 81). 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-119. - Reserved. 
Sec. 14-120. - License; denial by finance director; appeal. 
(a)  If the finance director, after investigation of the applicant, determines that the applicant does not meet the requirements as set forth in this article, the finance director need not place such application on an agenda for city council action, but shall send written notice to the applicant that the license is denied and state the reasons for such denial. Any applicant denied a permit by the finance director may appeal such decision to the city council as set forth in this article. 
(b)  The applicant may, within ten days of notification of an adverse decision, submit a notice of appeal to the finance director. Said notice of appeal shall be in writing, addressed to the city council, shall specify the subject matter of the appeal, the date of the original application and any amended applications, the date of the adverse decision (or receipt of notice thereof); the basis of the appeal, and the action requested of the city council. 
(c)  The finance director, after timely receipt of a notice of appeal, shall place the appeal on the agenda of a regular or special city council meeting occurring not less than seven nor more than 30 days after receipt of the notice of appeal. The finance director shall notify the applicant in writing of the date and time set for the hearing on appeal. 
(d)  Whenever the finance director has scheduled an appeal before the city council, at the time and date set therefor, the city council shall receive such relevant testimony or other evidence from the applicant, from city employees, interested parties, or other persons having relevant evidence. The city council shall not be bound by formal rules of evidence as used in courts of law. The applicant shall have the right to present evidence and to question or examine witnesses. 
(e)  The city council may sustain, modify or overrule the decision complained of. The decision of the city council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93; Ord. No. O-01-81, § 3, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 14-121. - Restrictions on transferability and addition of additional partners or shareholders. 
(a)  No license issued hereunder shall be sold, given, transferred, or assigned by any licensee, or by operation of law, to any other person, persons, or entities. Any such sale, gift, transfer, or assignment, or attempted sale, gift, transfer, or assignment shall be deemed to constitute a voluntary surrender of the license and such license shall thereafter be null and void; provided, however, if the licensee is a partnership or corporation, and one or more of the partners or shareholders, as the case may be, should die, one or more of the surviving partners or shareholders who were partners or shareholders at the time of issuance of the license, and who wish to carry on the business by their service in a managing capacity, may acquire, by purchase or otherwise, the interest of the deceased partner or shareholder without effecting a surrender or termination of such license, and in such case, the new licensee shall immediately notify the city clerk in writing. An adult entertainment establishment license issued to a corporation shall be deemed terminated and void when either any outstanding stock of the corporation is sold, transferred, or assigned after the issuance of such a license, or any stock authorized but not issued at the time of the granting of a license hereunder is thereafter issued and sold, transferred, or assigned. 
(b)  No licensee shall change the name or location of the establishment without obtaining a new license. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-122. - Forfeiture of license for nonuse. 
Any holder of an adult entertainment license hereunder who shall begin the operation of the business as authorized by the license, but who shall for a period of three consecutive months thereafter cease to operate the business as authorized by the license, shall, upon completion of said three months period, automatically forfeit his license, which license shall, by virtue of said failure to operate, be canceled without the necessity of any further action on the part of the city. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-123. - License fee. 
The annual license fee for an adult entertainment license shall be $5,000.00. Said license fee shall be issued on a calendar year basis and shall not be prorated. Licenses are not transferrable. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-124. - Annual renewal required. 
All licenses hereunder shall be issued on a calendar year basis and shall expire on December 31st of each year. All licensees hereunder shall be required to renew their licenses annually on forms provided by the city. The fee to renew an adult entertainment license shall be $5,000.00. Applications for renewal shall be filed with the finance director on forms provided by the finance director between October 15th and November 15th of each year, together with the renewal fee. Any application for renewal of an adult entertainment license not received by the finance director by November 15th shall result in a late filing fee of $500.00 being assessed against the licensee. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93; Ord. No. O-01-81, § 3, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 14-125. - Zones where establishment permitted. 
No adult entertainment establishment, adult business, adult video store, bathhouse, or escort bureau shall be located on any premises unless the location has been zoned C-2 under the zoning laws of City of Douglasville. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 14-126. - Severability and conflict. 
Should any section or provision of this article be declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of this article as a whole nor any part thereof other than the part so declared to be invalid or unconstitutional. 
Should any section or provision of this article be in conflict with any other ordinance, rule, regulation, or law, then the more restrictive ordinance, rule, regulation, provision, requirement, or law shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. O-93-15, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Chapter 18 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2016-27, § 1(Exh. A) , adopted June 20, 2016, repealed the former Ch. 18, §§ 18-1, 18-2, 18-31—18-34, 18-51—18-56, 18-76—18-79, 18-101, 18-102, 18-131—18-137, 18-156, 18-157, 18-176—18-179, 18-201—18-204, 18-231, 18-232, 18-251—18-256, and enacted a new chapter as set out herein. The former Ch. 18 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for a detailed history of derivation. 
Charter reference— Authority to regulate, license animals and fowl, § 1.03(o). 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26; environment, ch. 38; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 58; animals in parks, § 62-42; traffic and vehicles, ch. 82; zoning, app. A.
