If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency occurs as a result of underreporting, a penalty of ten percent will be assessed for the period delinquent. Said assessment and penalty shall be due and payable within ten calendar days of receiving written notice of any such deficiencies. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95; Ord. No. O-01-81, § 4, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 26-27. - Tax registration to be revoked for failure to pay tax, file returns, permit inspection of books. 
Upon the failure of any business to pay said occupation tax or any part thereof before it becomes delinquent, or upon failure to make any of said returns within the time required herein, or upon failure to make a true return, or upon failure to amend a return to set forth the truth, or upon failure to permit inspection of its books as above provided, any business tax registration granted by the city under this article permitting the owner of said business to do business for the current year shall be, ipso facto, revoked. No new business tax registration shall be granted by the city for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax herein provided for is at that time unpaid, or to an individual, firm, or corporation who has failed to submit adequate records as requested by the city clerk in accordance with provisions found in section 26-22. In the case of those practitioners where the local government cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct business, the imposition of any lawful penalties permitted shall be pursued by the local government in the case of delinquent occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-28. - Effect of failure to comply with article provisions; continuing in business after tax registration revocation. 
Any persons, their managers, agents, or employees, who do business in said city after the registration for said business has been revoked as above, hereby required to make occupation tax returns, and who fail to make said returns within the time and in the manner herein provided, who refuse to amend such returns so as to set forth the truth, or who shall make false returns; and any persons, their managers, agents, or employees who refuse to permit an inspection of books in their charge when the officers, agents, employees, or representatives of the city request such inspection, during business hours, for the purpose of determining the accuracy of the returns herein provided for, shall be subject to penalties provided herein. In the case of those practitioners where the local government cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct business, the imposition of many lawful penalties shall be permitted and pursued by the local government in the case of delinquent occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-29. - Lien taken for delinquent occupation tax or fees. 
In addition to the other remedies herein provided for the collection of assessments for the occupation tax, administrative fees and regulatory fees herein levied, upon any assessment becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, the assessment shall bear interest at the rate of 1.5 percent per month from the date when such assessment or installment becomes delinquent, until execution issued. Additionally, upon any assessment becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid for more than 90 days, there shall be added a ten percent penalty. Upon any assessment becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid for more than 90 days, the city clerk shall issue execution for the correct amount of said assessment against the persons, partnership, or corporation liable for said assessment. The execution shall bear interest on the assessment, excluding any penalty and pre-execution interest, at the rate of 1.5 percent per month, and the lien shall cover the property in the city of persons, partnership, or corporation liable for said assessment, all as provided by the ordinances of said city and the laws of Georgia, and the defendant in said execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the applicable laws in regard to tax executions. When a nulla bona entry has been entered by proper authority upon an execution issued by the appropriate officer or official against any person defaulting on the occupation tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due him or her as though he or she had never defaulted in the payment of the taxes. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-30. - Appeals and qualifications for board of adjustments and appeals. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation who is of the opinion that the occupation tax has been incorrectly assessed or that the major line classification is incorrect or that the registration has been incorrectly denied shall have the right to appeal to the board of adjustments and appeals within ten calendar days of having been notified of the disputed decision by the city clerk's office. A written appeal stating the position of the appealing party to the board of adjustment and appeals must be made within ten calendar days of any adverse decision. A hearing by the board of adjustments and appeals on the dispute shall be held within ten calendar days of written appeal to the board of adjustment and appeals. If the appealing part is still aggrieved after the decision of the said board he/she may file a written appeal to the city council within ten calendar days of receiving said adverse decision. 
(b)  Reference to the board of adjustments and appeals within this section shall refer to such board consisting of at least three members of the city council. Such members shall be selected by the mayor and approved by the city council by resolution, to serve for such term as the city council shall select and at the pleasure of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-31. - Posting of emergency information. 
All businesses, including separate business establishments within one building, shall post in a conspicuous place the current name and telephone number or numbers of a person for contact in the event of an emergency. It shall be the duty of the applicant to comply with this requirement. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-32. - Advertisement. 
Any person advertising by signs, cards, circulars, newspaper advertising, radio advertising or otherwise, that he/she is in business of any kind the city shall be held liable for the registration, if any, required of such business. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-33. - Miscellaneous registration provisions. 
(a)  If there is any business not specifically and particularly mentioned or provided for by the terms of this article or any other ordinance now in effect, the finance director and/or the city manager are authorized and empowered to require that a registration be obtained for the conduct of such business, and to fix the amount thereof prior to the engaging in such business, and no person shall engage in any business without having paid such occupation tax, but the finance director and/or city manager shall be required to notify the city council of any such action within 30 days. 
(b)  The maximum occupation tax set by the finance director and/or city manager shall be the maximum as set forth in this article for a business mentioned in this article and the minimum shall be the minimum as set forth in this article for a business mentioned in this article. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95; Ord. No. O-01-81, § 5, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 26-34. - Amendment, repeal of provision. 
This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the city council to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Said amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the jurisdiction of additional occupation taxes upon the same person, property, or business. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-35. - Applications of provisions to prior ordinance. 
This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereinafter passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in said ordinance or ordinances, or failure to comply with any other provisions hereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee, or assessment shall be fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-36. - Enforcement of provisions. 
It is hereby made the duty of the city clerk and other duly appointed persons to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed; and to summon all violators of the same not exempt from criminal penalties to appear before the court. Notwithstanding any ordinance to the contrary, attorneys at law are hereby exempted from any and all criminal sanctions for failure to comply with this chapter, and are subject only to civil penalties for failure to comply. It is hereby made the further duty of the city clerk, police chief, members of the police department, building department, code compliance officer and their assistants to inspect all registrations issued by the city, as often as in their judgment it may seem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95; Ord. No. O-97-58, § 1, 9-2-97; Ord. No. O-2018-9 , § 2, 3-5-18) 
Sec. 26-37. - Requirement of public hearing before tax increase. 
After January 1, 1996, the city council shall conduct at least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax as set forth in the article. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-38. - Option to establish exemption or reduction in occupation tax. 
The city council may by subsequent ordinance or resolution provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax to one or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious, and the reasons shall be set forth in the minutes of the governing authority or a plan. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-39. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. 
Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-40. - Severability. 
If any section, provision, or clause of any part of this article shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, or if the provisions of any part of this article as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, such individuality shall not be construed to affect the portions of this article not so held to be invalid, or the application of this article to other circumstances not so held to be invalid. It is hereby declared as the intent that this article would have been adopted had such invalid portion not been included herein. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-41. - Repeal of conflicting provisions. 
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this article, and not preserved hereby, are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-42. - Revocation of registration. 
The city council, on the basis of citations issued by the city clerk or any duly authorized representative, or on the basis of citations issued by any law enforcement officer, shall have the right to suspend and/or revoke any registration issued under this chapter whenever the licensee shall do any of the following: 
(1)  Fail to confine the business operations to those normally associated with the particular registered activity; or 
(2)  Violate any city code, rule, regulation or ordinance pertaining directly or indirectly to the registered activity; or 
(3)  Violate any state or federal code, rule, regulation, ordinance or statute pertaining directly or indirectly to the registered activity. 
Any person alleged to have violated the provisions of this chapter shall be given written notice of such violation by a representative of the city and shall be entitled to have a hearing before the city council on any proposed suspension or revocation. At the hearing, the licensee shall be entitled to legal representation and shall have the right to present witnesses and to cross-examine any witnesses presented by the city. No hearing provided for herein shall be conducted sooner than ten days from the date of the issuance of the citation. The decision of the city council shall be rendered within ten days from the date of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-43. - Taxes on alcoholic beverages additional. 
Nothing herein shall affect any ordinance providing for the regulation of the sale of any form of alcoholic beverages and takes imposed thereon, such taxes being due and payable in addition to the occupational tax imposed hereby. Holders of licenses issued by the City of Douglasville for the sale of alcoholic beverages, both retail and wholesale, shall be in addition to this article be taxed in accordance with the applicable provisions of state law and the Alcoholic Beverage Code of the City of Douglasville. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-44. - Street sales restricted. 
Generally, the streets, sidewalks and alleys of the city shall not be used for the sale of any merchandise. The city council shall have authority, upon written application to the council, to make exception to this section for periods of one day at a time for the purpose of sidewalk sales, street festivals and the like. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-45. - Unlawful display. 
No person shall carry or display any city license or permit which has been revoked or has expired or which has not been lawfully acquired and issued. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-46. - Inspection by building official. 
The building official of the City of Douglasville or his duly authorized agent shall inspect every business address within the corporate limits of the City of Douglasville list[ed] on the business license application as a place of conducting business, of every person, firm or corporation to verify that the business location is properly zoned, the building structure is suitable for the type of business to be located in the structure, that no building code violations exist and that a certificate of occupancy has been issued for the structure, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Secs. 26-47—26-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TEMPORARY BUSINESS REGISTRATION 

Sec. 26-51. - General provisions. 
A person, firm, or corporation desiring to open a business at a location not properly zoned for the business may make application to the city council for temporary registration under the terms and conditions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-52. - Application. 
An applicant desiring temporary registration of a business for a location not properly zoned shall make an application to the finance director for said registration. Such application shall state the name and address of the applicant, the location and legal description of the location at which such temporary business registration is sought, and the current zoning classification of the location. As a part of the application, the applicant shall submit satisfactory evidence that a rezoning application or application for a land use permit regarding such location has been properly filed with the proper public officials and that all required fees regarding zoning application have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95; Ord. No. O-2013-53, § 9, 12-16-13) 
Sec. 26-53. - Action by city council. 
Upon receipt of an application for temporary registration under this division, the city clerk shall forward such application to city council for action. The council shall consider the nature of the business sought to be conducted, the location and characterization of the location at which such business is sought to be conducted, the merits of the application in general, and other factors and information as the council deems relevant. The grant of temporary registration shall be considered on a case-by-case basis and shall be solely within the discretion of the council. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-54. - Fee and duration. 
(a)  Any temporary registration granted by the council shall be for a period not to exceed 90 days. Temporary registrations shall not be subject to renewal by the city council. At the expiration of a temporary business registration, the holder thereof shall immediately make application for a regular registration as elsewhere provided by this chapter. 
(b)  The fee for temporary business registration shall be $50.00 and this cost of processing said application shall not apply as partial payment or credit towards the regular, full term occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Sec. 26-55. - No vested rights. 
No applicant under this section who applies for temporary registration shall, as a result of being granted a temporary registration and/or as a result of invested time, labor, materials, and funds in the establishment of a business at a requested location or in improvements or modifications regarding such location, acquire any vested rights to a rezoning of such location or the grant of a land use permit at such location. Any such investment of time, labor, materials, and funds are made at the risk of the applicant, and shall not obligate the council to take any further favorable action regarding the rezoning of such locations. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 12-18-95) 
Secs. 26-56—26-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PEDDLERS, TRANSIENT MERCHANTS, AND DOOR-TO-DOOR SALESPERSONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2013-52, § 1, Exh. A, adopted Dec. 4, 2013, repealed the former Art. III, §§ 26-111—26-119, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1977, §§ 16-36—16-43; Ord. No. O-95-11, §§ 1—8, 5-1-95; Ord. No. O-95-11, §§ 1—8, 5-1-95; Ord. No. O-01-81, § 5, 12-3-01; Ord. No. O-03-35, § 1, 2, 10-20-03; and Ord. No. O-04-14, § 2, 4-19-04. 

Sec. 26-111. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Charitable organization means any benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary (of, relating to, or supported by charity or alms) corporation, partnership, limited liability company, association, joint-stock company, trust, unincorporated organization or individual who solicits or obtains contributions solicited from the general public, any part of which contributions is used for charitable purposes. 
Charitable purpose means any charitable, benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary purpose for religion, health, education, social welfare, arts and humanities, environment, civic or public interest. 
Door-to-door salesperson means any person who solicits orders on behalf of a firm, corporation, company, association, partnership or individual of any goods, wares or merchandise, or other things of value by traveling from house to house. 
Handicapped means any physical, mental, or neurological impairment which severely restricts a person's mobility, manual dexterity, or ability to climb stairs; substantial loss of sight or hearing; loss of one or more limbs or use thereof; or significantly diminished reasoning capacity. 
Peddler means any person who sells or solicits for sale any new or used goods, wares, merchandise, produce, service or other things of value, who does not possess a certificate of occupancy, selling or offering for sale any of such things to either merchants or customers. 
Transient merchant means any person, firm or corporation, as principal or agent, or both, which is not a regular retail or wholesale merchant with a permanent place of business in this state, but rather one who displays samples, goods, wares, or merchandise in any lot, building, room, structure or vehicle, for the purpose of securing orders for the sale of such item or items of like kind or quality for future or immediate delivery, or one who sells food, drink, produce or like products from a temporary site or structure. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-52, § 1, Exh. A, 12-4-13) 
Sec. 26-112. - Exclusions. 
The terms "transient merchant" and "peddler" and "door-to-door salesperson" shall not include any person, firm or corporation which: 
(1)  Sells directly to consumers only such produce or other direct farm products, as the seller has produced himself. 
(2)  Solicits sales for charitable organizations, charitable purposes, or on behalf of religious organizations, political organizations or political candidates. 
(3)  Conducts business at any industry or association trade show, or at any craft show or festival of not more than three days in duration. 
(4)  Sells items at a rummage, garage, flea market, antique or similar sale where such person, firm or corporation is a resident of this state or has a permanent place of business within this city and such sale is not part of the regular business activity of such person, firm or corporation. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-52, § 1, Exh. A, 12-4-13) 
Sec. 26-113. - Registration required; duration of registration. 
Each peddler, transient merchant and door-to-door sales person who does business within this city shall be required to obtain a registration from the finance director, in the manner specified in this article. Every such registration shall be valid for a continuous period of 15 days. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-52, § 1, Exh. A, 12-4-13) 
Sec. 26-114. - Requirements for corporations; registered agents. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any peddler or transient merchant or door-to-door salesperson which is a corporation to engage in business within the city unless such corporation shall comply with all applicable provisions of O.C.G.A. section 14-2-101 et. seq., relating to corporations and obtain a registration. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any peddler or transient merchant or door-to-door salesperson which is not a corporation to engage in business within the city unless such person shall have and maintain a registered agent or agents as required by section 26-116 and shall obtain a registration. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-52, § 1, Exh. A, 12-4-13) 
Sec. 26-115. - Applications. 
(a)  All peddlers and transient merchants and door-to-door salespersons shall file an application for a registration with the office of the finance director. Such application shall include but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  The name and permanent address of the individual peddler or transient merchant or door-to-door salesperson, and if applicable the name and address of the corporate peddler's or transient merchant's or door-to-door salesperson's registered agent or office. 
(2)  The type of business to be conducted. 
(3)  The date and place of incorporation, when such peddler or transient merchant is a corporation. 
(4)  The address, location or general area where business is to be conducted. 
(5)  An administrative fee of $65.00 per registered individual, in addition to the base administrative fee required by section 26-3. 
(b)  At the time the registration application is filed, the applicant shall pay all regulatory fees due under section 26-3. Registrations under this division are not transferable. 
(c)  As a part of the registration application for transient merchants, each applicant designating any one or more stationary addresses or locations where business is to be conducted shall, prior to filing of such application with the office of the finance director, submit said application to the building official for approval. The building official shall approve applications designating addresses and locations for business where traffic will not be unduly impeded, and where any stationary non-motorized structures used to store inventory, samples, or other business materials is sufficiently stable to withstand inclement weather. 
(d)  As a part of the registration application, each transient merchant applicant designating any one or more stationary addresses or locations owned by another where business is to be conducted, shall submit with such application a written statement showing the consent of the property owner (and lessee, if any) for the applicant to transact business thereon. 
(e)  As a part of the registration application, each individual applicant and each representative for a corporate applicant shall submit to a criminal background check by the police department, and obtain a photo identification card bearing a current photograph of the applicant. 
(f)  An individual applicant who is 65 years old or older, or one who is handicapped, shall be exempt from all regulatory fees, but shall still be required to make application for a registration with the office of the finance director and obtain and pay the administrative fee for a photo identification card from the police department. Any handicapped applicant will be required to provide proof of handicap either by providing state handicap identification or a letter of handicap from a licensed physician. Any applicant, who is 65 years old or older, shall provide proof of age either by birth certificate or state identification. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-52, § 1, Exh. A, 12-4-13) 
Sec. 26-116. - Denial of applications; revocation of registration. 
(a)  Applications for registration for individual peddlers and transient merchants and door-to-door salespersons shall be denied by the police department for: 
(1)  Any person who has been convicted within the past seven years of any felony offense; or 
(2)  Any person who has been convicted within the past seven years of any misdemeanor offense involving theft, fraud or physical violence; or 
(3)  Any person who has, within the past seven years, had revoked his business license or any license issued by a local government. 
(b)  Denial of registration may be appealed by the applicant to the mayor and council, by filing of a written appeal with the city clerk not later than seven days after dispatch of written notice to the applicant. On appeal, the mayor and council may correct any errors of law or fact, upon appeal, but may not grant a registration to any individual whose background is in violation of the requirements of this section. 
(c)  Registrations may be revoked otherwise sanctioned in the same manner and upon the same basis as for the revocation of business licenses and occupation tax registrations. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-52, § 1, Exh. A, 12-4-13) 
Sec. 26-117. - Display of photo identification. 
Photo identification cards shall be displayed at all times while the applicant or representative conducts business in the city, and each shall exhibit such registration at the request of any person. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-52, § 1, Exh. A, 12-4-13) 
Sec. 26-118. - Loud noise and amplification devices prohibited. 
No registration holder under this article shall shout, ring bells, blow horns, make loud noises or use any radio or amplifying system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks or other public places within the city for the purpose of attracting attention to the goods, wares or merchandise which such registrant intends to sell. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-52, § 1, Exh. A, 12-4-13) 
Sec. 26-119. - Reserved. 
Sec. 26-120. - Additional regulations for transient merchants. 
(a)  Transient merchants shall conduct business only in locations zoned general commercial and in accordance with Appendix A—Zoning of the City Code. 
(b)  All vehicles must be removed from the transient merchant's location at the end of each workday. Only one vehicle, other than any vehicle of a customer present at the sales location, is allowed for each location during business hours. 
(c)  No transient merchant shall transact business between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-52, § 1, Exh. A, 12-4-13) 
Sec. 26-121. - Additional regulations for peddlers. 
(a)  Peddlers shall park the vehicle associated with the business on asphalt or concrete and out of the right-of-way. 
(b)  No tents, tables, boxes, chairs, or any accessory to the business shall be allowed in connection with sales. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-52, § 1, Exh. A, 12-4-13) 
Sec. 26-122. - Additional regulations for door-to-door salespersons. 
(a)  The police department shall provide to each registered door-to-door salesperson an information card, and the door-to-door salesperson shall present this card to each household he visits. It is the responsibility of the door-to-door sales person to make sufficient copies of the information card to furnish to each household he visits. Such card shall contain information as required by the police department. 
(b)  At any home where a "no soliciting" sign is posted, no soliciting shall be made. 
(c)  No door-to-door salesperson shall enter a home except at the express invitation of the occupant. 
(d)  Any residential occupant may refuse entry or to ask the door-to-door salesperson to leave the premises, after allowing entry, and, if the door-to-door salesperson should fail to leave the premises after such instructions, he shall be in violation of the laws of this state and ordinances of the city. 
(e)  Any purchaser of the product of the door-to-door salesperson has the right to cancel a home solicitation service agreement any time until midnight on the business day after the day on which the purchaser signs the agreement, provided the purchaser gives notice of the cancellation to the seller at the place of business as set forth in the agreement or by certified mail, return receipt requested, which shall be posted not later than midnight on the day following execution of the agreement. 
(f)  At each house where a door-to-door salesperson calls for sales, the door-to-door salesperson shall announce to the owner or occupant of the home his name and that he has been issued a permit by or has registered with the City of Douglasville as a door-to-door salesperson, and shall announce the purpose of his call and present the card provided for by this division and shall allow time for the occupant or owner to read the card. 
(g)  A door-to-door salesperson shall at all times maintain a courteous decorum and shall not use opprobrious words to any homeowner or occupant. No door-to-door salesperson shall remain upon the premises of an occupant or owner after such occupant or owner has requested the door-to-door salesperson to leave or has indicated that he is not interested in purchasing the door-to-door salesperson's product. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful for any door-to-door salesperson to represent by word, action or deed that the issuance of a permit or registration by the city in any way represents approval of either the action of the door-to-door salesperson or his product or organization. 
(i)  If a door-to-door salesperson shall secure an order from an owner or occupant, such door-to-door salesperson shall inform the owner or occupant as to his rights under the home solicitation act of the state. This may be done by the door-to-door salesperson leaving a written card or document specifying the rights of a homeowner or occupant under the Retail Installment and Home Solicitation Sales Act (O.C.G.A. § 10-1-1 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. O-2013-52, § 1, Exh. A, 12-4-13) 
Secs. 26-123—26-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NONPROFIT FOOD SALES AND FOOD SERVICE 

Sec. 26-130. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Nonprofit food sales and food service means the temporary sale or service of food items by an organization at an event sponsored by an organization and an authority. 
(2)  Organization means an organization exempt from taxes under paragraph (1) of subsection (a) of O.C.G.A. Section 48-7-25 and under Section 501(d) or paragraphs (1) through (8) or paragraph (10) of Section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code, as that code is defined in O.C.G.A. Section 48-1-2. 
(3)  Authority means an authority established by general or local legislation for the City of Douglasville, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. O-97-28, § 5, 3-17-97) 
Sec. 26-131. - Permits, duration, subsequent permits. 
Upon proper application and payment of a permit fee, the finance director shall issue to any organization a permit for nonprofit food sales and food service. A permit shall be valid for a period of 48 hours or less, and another permit shall not be issued to the organization holding such permit until five days have elapsed from the date of expiration of the permit. 
(Ord. No. O-97-28, § 5, 3-17-97; Ord. No. O-2013-53, § 10, 12-16-13) 
Sec. 26-132. - Health standards. 
(a)  Food shall be in sound condition, free from spoilage, filth, or other contamination and shall be safe for human consumption. Food shall be obtained from sources that comply with all laws relating to food and food labeling. The use of food in hermetically sealed containers that was not prepared in a licensed food processing establishment is prohibited. 
(b)  At all times, including while being stored, prepared, displayed, served, or transported, food shall be protected from potential contamination, including dust, insects, rodents, unclean equipment and utensils, unnecessary handling, flooding, drainage, and overhead leakage or overhead drippage from condensation. The temperature of potentially hazardous food shall be either 45 degrees Fahrenheit or below or 140 degrees Fahrenheit or above at all times. 
(c)  The preparation of the following potentially hazardous foods is prohibited: 
(1)  Pastries filled with cream or synthetic cream; 
(2)  Custards; 
(3)  Products similar to the products listed in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subsection: or 
(4)  Salads containing meat, poultry, eggs, or fish. 
(d)  Frozen desserts shall only be produced using commercially pasteurized mixes or ingredients. Suitable utensils must be provided to eliminate hand contact with the cooked product. All utensils and equipment shall be cleaned periodically as necessary to prevent a buildup of food. 
(e)  Ice that is consumed or that contacts food shall be from an approved source and protected from contamination until used. Ice used for cooling stored food shall not be used for human consumption. Food shall be served in an individual meal type of container and handed to the customer. Food items shall not be transported for sale at any other location or sold, held, or reused at another event. 
(f)  A convenient handwashing facility shall be available for employee handwashing. This facility shall consist of, at least, warm running water and individual paper towels. 
(g)  This Code section shall in no way be construed to allow the sale of food items which have been packaged, bottled, or canned in facilities not approved by the law. 
(Ord. No. O-97-28, § 5, 3-17-97) 
Sec. 26-133. - Penalties for violation of article. 
Violations of this article are declared to be unlawful, and violations shall be punished as provided in section 1-3 of the Code of the City of Douglasville. 
(Ord. No. O-97-28, § 5, 3-17-97) 
Secs. 26-134—26-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BAIL BONDSMEN[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-97-28, § 1, adopted March 17, 1997, renumbered Art. IV as Art. V. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion of said ordinance O-97-28. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-151. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Professional bondsmen means all persons who hold themselves out as signers or sureties of bail bonds for compensation, and who are licensed as provided in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 7-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-152. - Persons prohibited from signing bonds. 
No attorney-at-law and no official authorized to admit to bail, nor any city, or county official, shall become surety on any bond. 
(Code 1977, § 7-2) 
Sec. 26-153. - Power of attorney. 
All professional bondsmen must attach to each bail bond a duly executed power of attorney in an amount of at least the penal sum of the bond. This section shall not apply to any card or certificate of membership of any automobile club. 
(Code 1977, § 7-3) 
Sec. 26-154. - Fees of sureties. 
Professional bondsmen shall not, when receiving compensation, charge or receive more than ten percent of the first $500.00 of the principal amount of the bond and five percent of the principal of such bond over $500.00 from the defendant or from anyone acting for the defendant. 
(Code 1977, § 7-4) 
Sec. 26-155. - Prenumbered receipt as evidence of payment. 
(a)  All professional bondsmen engaged in the bail bond business, who accept money or any other consideration for any bail bond which they execute, must for each and every payment received, give to the person paying the money or giving the consideration, a prenumbered receipt as evidence of payment, which receipt shall state the date, name of the principal, amount of money or consideration received and purpose for which received, number of the power of attorney form attached to the bond, penal sum of the bond, and name of person making payment or giving consideration. 
(b)  All professional bondsmen must retain a duplicate copy of each receipt issued as part of their records. 
(Code 1977, § 7-5) 
Sec. 26-156. - Suggesting employment of attorney. 
Professional bondsmen shall not suggest or advise the employment or name for employment any attorney or attorneys to represent the defendant, during the negotiations for the bondsmen to sign the bond or subsequent thereto. 
(Code 1977, § 7-6) 
Sec. 26-157. - Soliciting business. 
Professional bondsmen shall not solicit business as such bondsmen, nor shall they lounge about or around the city jail, for the purpose of engaging in or soliciting business as such bondsmen. No officer or personnel of the city jail shall suggest to or advise in any manner whatever any prisoner of the city, the employment of the services of any professional bondsman to sign bonds for appearance in court at any time. 
(Code 1977, § 7-7) 
Sec. 26-158. - Participation in defense prohibited. 
Professional bondsmen shall not advise defendants, principals in bonds signed by them, or give any directions in the defense or disposition of the cases in which bonds are signed. 
(Code 1977, § 7-8) 
Sec. 26-159. - Payments to and by. 
No professional bondsman becoming surety on a bond and receiving the compensation in the case for signing such bond as surety, shall thereafter receive any other sum in the case to the final disposition of the same. 
(Code 1977, § 7-9) 
Sec. 26-160. - Forfeiture of bond, surrender of custody of defendant. 
(a)  Upon a forfeiture of the bond, the surety shall have the right to surrender into custody the defendant or the principal in such bond without the return of any money paid for the signing of such bond. 
(b)  The nonappearance of defendant on first call of docket shall be declared as bail forfeited. The forfeiture shall be paid within 30 days of the date of forfeiture, however, at any time within 30 days from the date of forfeiture, the city recorder may upon proper showing: 
(1)  Of a satisfactory explanation of the breach of the bond; 
(2)  That the defendant was at the time of required appearance adjudicated insane and confined in an institution or hospital; or 
(3)  That the defendant was at the time of required appearance confined in a jail or prison within the state for a felony; 
direct that the forfeiture of the bond be discharged, or if the forfeiture has been paid, shall direct that remission of the forfeiture be made to the surety; provided that the court may require, as a condition to discharge or remission, the payment of costs and expenses incurred. 
(Code 1977, § 7-10) 
Sec. 26-161. - Condition of the bond. 
If a person is admitted to bail for his appearance in recorder's court, the condition of the bail bond shall be that he will appear for such hearing, at the time and date specified on copy of charges to answer the charge, or at such other time or times set by the court, to answer the charge, and will submit himself to the orders and processes of the city recorder trying the case, and will not depart without leave of same. 
(Code 1977, § 7-11) 
Sec. 26-162. - Judgment absolute. 
(a)  The city recorder shall issue an order of judgment absolute 30 days after date of forfeiture. The professional bondsman, as surety on the bond, shall then and there pay to the court the penal sum of the bond. 
(b)  This judgment absolute becomes a final disposition and relieves surety and defendant of any further obligation to the city. 
(Code 1977, § 7-12) 
Sec. 26-163. - Canceling the bond. 
When the condition of the bond is satisfied or the forfeiture of the bond has been discharged or remitted, the city recorder shall make an order canceling the bond. Conviction or acquittal of the defendant shall satisfy the terms of the bond written by any bail bondsman. 
(Code 1977, § 7-13) 
Sec. 26-164. - To have equal access. 
All professional bondsmen who hold a currently effective license issued by the finance director shall be entitled to equal access to the jail of this city for the purpose of making bond. 
(Code 1977, § 7-14; Ord. No. O-01-81, § 6, 12-3-01) 
Sec. 26-165. - Employee termination. 
Any professional bondsman who terminates the appointment of any employee authorized to sign bonds, shall immediately file written notice thereof with the chief of police and the city clerk, together with a statement that he has given or mailed notice to the employee. Such notice filed shall state the reasons, if any, for such termination. Information so furnished shall be privileged and shall not be used as evidence in any action against the professional bondsman. All bonds signed by a terminated employee prior to such notification shall be binding upon the professional bondsman. 
(Code 1977, § 7-15) 
Sec. 26-166. - Prohibited activities. 
It shall be unlawful for any professional bondsman to: 
(1)  Pay a fee or rebate or give or promise anything of value to a jailer, policeman, peace officer, city recorder, or any other person who has power to arrest or to hold in custody; or to any city official or city employee in order to secure a settlement, compromise, remission or reduction of the amount of any bail bond thereof. 
(2)  Pay a fee or rebate or give anything of value to an attorney in bail bond matters, except in defense of any action of a bond. 
(3)  Pay a fee or rebate or give or promise anything of value to the principal or anyone in his behalf. 
(4)  Sign nor countersign in blank any bond, nor shall be given a power of attorney to, or otherwise authorize, anyone to countersign his name to bonds unless the person so authorized is directly employed by the bondsman giving such power of attorney. 
(Code 1977, § 7-16) 
Sec. 26-167. - Officer taking insufficient bail. 
Any person authorized to take bail, who takes bail which he knows to be insufficient, or accepts as surety any professional bondsman who is not qualified to act as surety, shall be guilty of an act of misconduct and shall be subject to disciplinary action by the department head or mayor and council. 
(Code 1977, § 7-17) 
Sec. 26-168. - Display of signs. 
(a)  Each professional bondsman duly licensed by the city shall be allowed to display a sign of his own making in a place designated by the chief of police, at or near the book in/book out section of the city jail. 
(b)  One sign per licensee shall be permitted and shall be limited to lettering and numbering of no more than three inches high and 1½ inches in width for each letter or numeral. 
(c)  Signs shall be limited to two lines to allow name of business at top and phone number at bottom. 
(d)  Signs shall be restricted to black and white in coloring, shall be of such overall dimensions as determined by the chief of police or mayor and council, and shall be hung in a place so designated on a first come first served priority. 
(Code 1977, § 7-18) 
Secs. 26-169—26-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 26-186. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a professional bondsman within this city without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1977, § 7-31) 
Sec. 26-187. - Issuance regulations. 
Every license required by the provisions of this article shall be issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 7-32) 
Sec. 26-188. - Qualifications. 
To qualify for license as a professional bondsman in the city, it must affirmatively appear that the: 
(1)  Applicant is a natural person who has reached the age of 18 years. 
(2)  Applicant is a citizen of the United States, has been a bona fide resident of this state for one year last past. 
(3)  Place of business of the applicant will be located in this state and that such applicant will be actively engaged in the bail bond business and maintain a place of business accessible to the public. 
(4)  Applicant is a person of high character and approved integrity and shall be vouched for by two other reputable citizens who are residents of this county. 
(5)  Applicant shall furnish with his application, a complete set of his fingerprints and a recent credential-size full face photograph of himself. The applicant's fingerprints shall be certified by the chief of police. 
(6)  Applicant can justify the sufficiency of his bonding ability by affidavit that he possesses the qualifications and sufficiency to become a surety, and in such affidavit shall describe his property, to which he proposes to justify as to his sufficiency, stating the encumbrances thereon, according to the standards as promulgated by the county sheriff. 
(Code 1977, § 7-33) 
Sec. 26-189. - Application fee. 
A fee of $10.00 shall be submitted with each application for a license required by the provisions of this article. Such fee shall be to defray the costs of conducting a character investigation of the applicant. 
(Code 1977, § 7-34) 
Sec. 26-190. - Termination. 
Any professional bondsman who discontinues writing bail bonds during the period for which he is licensed shall notify the chief of police and the city clerk and immediately return his license. 
(Code 1977, § 7-35) 
Sec. 26-191. - Denial, suspension, revocation. 
In addition to any other provision of this Code, the mayor and council may deny, suspend, revoke or refuse to renew any license issued in accordance with this division for any of the following causes: 
(1)  For any cause for which issuance of the license could have been refused had it then existed and been known to the mayor and council. 
(2)  Material misstatement, misrepresentation or fraud in obtaining the license. 
(3)  Misappropriation, conversion or unlawful withholding of money belonging to others and received in the conduct of business under the license. 
(4)  Conviction of a felony. 
(5)  Fraudulent or dishonest practices in the conduct of business under the license. 
(6)  Willful failure to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(7)  Willful failure to return collateral security to the principal when the principal is entitled thereto. 
(8)  When, in the judgment of the mayor and council, the licensee has in the conduct of affairs under the license, demonstrated incompetency or untrustworthiness, or conduct or practices rendering him unfit to carry on the bail bond business, or making his continuance in such business detrimental to the public interest, or that he is no longer in good faith carrying on the bail bond business, or that he is guilty of rebating or offering to rebate, or offering to divide his compensation, and for any or all such reasons is found by the mayor and council to be a source of detriment, injury or loss to the public. 
(Code 1977, § 7-36) 
Secs. 26-192—26-215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FIRE, BANKRUPT, GOING-OUT-OF-BUSINESS, ETC., SALES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-97-28, § 2, adopted March 17, 1997, renumbered Art. V as Art. VI. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion of said ordinance O-97-28. 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 42. 

Sec. 26-216. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Fire and other altered goods sale means a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the sale will offer goods damaged or altered by fire, smoke, water or other means. 
Going-out-of-business sale means a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that upon the disposal of the stock of goods on hand the business will cease and be discontinued, including but not limited to the following sales: adjuster's, adjustment, alteration, assignee's bankrupt, benefit of administrator's, benefit of creditor's, benefit of trustee's, building coming down, closing, creditor's committee, creditor's end, executor's final days, forced out, forced out of business, insolvent's last days, lease expires, liquidation, loss of lease, mortgage sale, receiver's, trustee's quitting business, and other like sales. 
Goods means and includes any goods, wares, merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated under this article. 
Removal of business sale means a sale held out in such manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the person conducting the sale will cease and discontinue business at the place of sale upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand and will then move to and resume business at a new location in the city or will then continue business from other existing locations in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 16-66) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-217. - Penalties for violation of article. 
Violations of this article are declared to be unlawful and violations shall be subject to punishment as provided by section 1-3 of the Code of the City of Douglasville. 
(Code 1977, § 16-81) 
Sec. 26-218. - General provisions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person advertising by newspaper, radio, posters or otherwise to represent that he is operating, offering or maintaining fire sales, wreck sales, bankrupt sales, or going-out-of-business sales and similar businesses whereby the public is led to believe that they are being offered merchandise at reduced rates on account of fires, wrecks, bankruptcies, closing-out or discontinuance of business when, in fact, such sales are not bona fide. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person conducting any sale, except judicial sales, whether the same is by auction or otherwise, of any goods, wares or merchandise which are claimed to be or have been in or damaged by fire, or which are claimed to be or have been sold or purchased on account of any fire, or which are or have been, or which are claimed to be the property of any bankrupt person who has failed in business or has made a general assignment or is or has made a general assignment, or is or has been in voluntary or involuntary bankruptcy, or which are being sold or offered for sale in any other way than through the usual channels of trade, to sell or offer for sale in such sale any goods, wares, or merchandise not so affected or damaged or to add to or to permit to be added to, or to bring into or permit to be brought into any store, warehouse or any building in the city, for the purpose of adding to such goods, wares, or merchandise so circumstanced or affected and which are on hand in any such store, warehouse or other building for the purpose of being sold at such sale. 
(Code 1977, § 16-65) 
Sec. 26-219. - License—Required. 
All persons shall secure a license from the city before selling or offering to sell any goods at a sale advertised or held out by any means to be one of the following kinds: 
(1)  Going-out-of-business sale; 
(2)  Removal of business sale; or 
(3)  Fire and other altered stock sale. 
(Code 1977, § 16-67) 
Sec. 26-220. - Same—Application. 
A person desiring to conduct a sale regulated by this article shall make a written application to the city, setting forth and containing the following information: 
(1)  The true name and address of the owner of the goods to be the object of the sale; 
(2)  The true name and address of the person from whom he purchased the goods to be sold, the price therefor, and, if not purchased, the manner of such acquisition; 
(3)  A description of the place where such sale is to be held; 
(4)  The nature of the occupancy, whether by lease or sublease, and the effective date of termination of such occupancy; 
(5)  The dates of the period of time in which the sale is to be conducted; 
(6)  A full and complete statement of the facts in regard to the sale, including the reason for the urgent and expeditious disposal of goods thereby and the manner in which the sale will be conducted; 
(7)  The means to be employed in advertising such sale together with the proposed content by any advertisement; and 
(8)  A complete and detailed inventory of the goods to be sold at such sale as disclosed by the applicant's records. Such inventory shall be attached to and become part of the required application. 
a.  All goods included in such inventory shall have been purchased by the applicant for resale on bona fide orders without cancellation privileges and shall not comprise goods purchased on consignment. 
b.  Such inventory shall not include goods ordered in contemplation of conducting a sale regulated under this article. Any unusual purchase or additions to the stock of goods of the business hereby affected within ten days before the filing of an application under this section shall be deemed to be of such character. 
(Code 1977, § 16-68) 
Sec. 26-221. - Same—Fee. 
Any applicant for a license under this article shall submit to the city a license fee of $100.00 with his application. 
(Code 1977, § 16-69) 
Sec. 26-222. - Same—Established business prerequisite. 
Any person who has not been the owner of the business advertised or described in the application for a license under this article for a period of at least 12 months prior to the date of the proposed sale shall not be granted a license, except upon the approval of the mayor and council of the city; provided, that upon the death of a person doing business in this city, his heirs, devisees or legatees shall have the right to apply at any time for a license under this article. 
(Code 1977, § 16-70) 
Sec. 26-223. - Same—Restricted to one place of business. 
Where a person applying for a license under this article operates more than one place of business, the license issued shall apply only to the one store or branch specified in the application. No other store or branch shall advertise or represent that it is cooperating with it or in any way participating in the licensed sale, nor shall the store or branch conducting the licensed sale advertise or represent that any other store or branch is cooperating with it or participating in any way in the licensed sale. 
(Code 1977, § 16-71) 
Sec. 26-224. - Same—Term. 
A license issued under this article shall authorize the sale described in the application for a period of not more than 30 consecutive days, Sundays and legal holidays excluded, following the issuance thereof; provided, that a longer period may be designated by the mayor and council of the city upon good cause shown. 
(Code 1977, § 16-72) 
Sec. 26-225. - Same—Limitation as to type of sale. 
A license issued under this article shall authorize only the one type of sale described in the application at the location named therein. 
(Code 1977, § 16-73) 
Sec. 26-226. - Same—Nontransferable. 
Any license provided for by this article shall not be assignable or transferable. 
(Code 1977, § 16-74) 
Sec. 26-227. - Surrender of other licenses for going-out-of-business sale. 
Upon being issued a license under this article for a going-out-of-business sale, the licensee shall surrender to the city all other business licenses he may hold at that time applicable to the location and goods covered by the application for a license under this article. 
(Code 1977, § 16-75) 
Sec. 26-228. - Interval between sales. 
Any person who has held a sale, as regulated under this article, at the location stated in the application, within one year past from the date of such application, shall not be granted a license, except upon the approval of the mayor and council of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 16-76) 
Sec. 26-229. - Limitation on goods to be sold. 
A license issued under this article shall authorize only the sale of goods described in the inventory attached to the application. 
(Code 1977, § 16-77) 
Sec. 26-230. - Duties of licensees. 
A licensee under this article shall: 
(1)  Adhere to inventory. Make no additions whatsoever, during the period of the licensed sale, to the stock of goods set forth in the inventory attached to the application for license; 
(2)  Advertise properly. Refrain from employing any untrue, deceptive or misleading advertising; 
(3)  Adhere to advertising. Conduct the licensed sale in strict conformity with any advertising or holding out incident thereto; 
(4)  Keep duplicate inventory. Keep available at the place of sale a duplicate copy of the inventory submitted with the application and shall present such duplicate to inspecting officials upon request; and 
(5)  Segregate noninventoried goods. Keep any other goods separate and apart from the goods listed in the filed inventory as being objects of sale and shall make such distinction clear to the public by placing tags on all inventoried goods in and about the place of sale apprising the public of the status of all such goods. 
(Code 1977, § 16-78) 
Sec. 26-231. - Effect of article. 
The provisions of this article are intended to augment and be in addition to the provisions of article II of this chapter. Where this article imposes a greater restriction upon persons, premises, businesses or practices than is imposed by article II, the provisions of this article shall control. 
(Code 1977, § 16-79) 
Sec. 26-232. - Applicability of article. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following persons: 
(1)  Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials. 
(3)  Duly licensed auctioneers, selling at auction. 
(4)  Any publisher of a newspaper, magazine or other publication who publishes in good faith, any advertisement, without knowledge of its false, deceptive or misleading character, or without knowledge that the provisions of this article have not been complied with. 
(Code 1977, § 16-80) 
Secs. 26-233—26-255. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - YARD SALES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-97-28, § 3, adopted March 17, 1997, renumbered Art. VI as Art. VII. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion of said ordinance O-97-28. 

Sec. 26-256. - Title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as an Ordinance Regulating Yard Sales in the City of Douglasville. 
(Code 1977, § 16-52) 
Sec. 26-257. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City means the City of Douglasville. 
Household items means goods and wares normally associated with the household, including but not limited to furniture, furnishings, linens, silverware, flatware, chinaware, glassware, utensils, supplies, equipment and appliances, televisions, radios, musical instruments, and clothing. The terms shall not include automobiles, but shall include automotive accessories, such as radios. 
Not in the course of ordinary business means an enterprise which is not a normal source of income for the person so engaged but is one that is occasional or irregular, including but not limited to yard sales, garage sales, attic sales, rummage sales, flea markets, swap meets, etc. 
Person means any individual, corporation or partnership, and includes the plural. 
Yard sale shall have the meaning ascribed to it as indicated in the zoning ordinance of the City of Douglasville. 
(Code 1977, § 16-53; Ord. No. O-99-48, § 1, 12-9-99) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-258. - Penalty. 
Failure to file notice or other violation of this article shall constitute a violation punishable under the terms of the Charter of the City of Douglasville. 
(Code 1977, § 16-59) 
Sec. 26-259. - Permit required. 
Any person who conducts a yard sale or allows the same to be conducted upon his property shall first apply for and have issued to him a permit from the planning and zoning director. 
(Ord. No. O-99-48, § 2, 12-9-99; Ord. No. O-02-17, § 1, 5-7-02) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-99-48, § 2, adopted Dec. 9, 1999 repealed sections 26-259—26-263 in their entirety and replaced them with new sections 26-259—26-262. Former sections 26-259—26-263 pertained to similar material and derived from the Code of 1977, §§ 16-54—16-58. 
Sec. 26-260. - Permit application. 
(a)  Any application for a yard sale permit shall be signed by the applicant, shall be filed at least 24 hours in advance of commencement of the sale and shall include the following: 
(1)  The name, address, and phone number for any person conducting, sponsoring or promoting the yard sale. 
(2)  The location at which the sale is to be conducted. 
(3)  The date or dates on which the yard sale is to be conducted, and the time period or periods of the day during which it is proposed to carry on the sale. 
(b)  There shall be no fee for any yard sale permit. 
(Ord. No. O-99-48, § 2, 12-9-99; Ord. No. O-01-81, § 7, 12-3-01; Ord. No. O-02-17, § 1, 5-7-02; Ord. No. O-2017-25 , § 1, 6-19-17) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following section 26-259. 
Sec. 26-261. - Exhibition of permit. 
A copy of the permit required by this article shall be posted conspicuously in or at the place named therein for the yard sale. Any permit shall be available for inspection at any time during the sale, and shall be valid only for the times, dates and place specified therein. 
(Ord. No. O-99-48, § 2, 12-9-99) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following section 26-259. 
Sec. 26-262. - Inspection. 
Any police officer or city code compliance officer shall have the right to enter any premises showing evidence sufficient to alert the general public of any ongoing enterprise such as regulated in this article, for the purpose of inspection or enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-99-48, § 2, 12-9-99; Ord. No. O-2018-9 , § 2, 3-5-18) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following section 26-259. 
Sec. 26-263. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— See editor's note following section 26-259. 
Secs. 26-264—26-280. - Reserved.
