Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 10; drunkenness, drinking in open public places, § 10-3; general liquor regulations, ch. 10-121; pouring outlet regulations, § 10-154; animals, ch. 18; cruelty to animals, § 18-101 et seq.; civil emergencies, ch. 30; false fire alarms, § 42-1. 

Sec. 58-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-01-20, § 1, adopted April 2, 2001, repealed § 58-1 in its entirety. Formerly said section pertained to interference with officers. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 58-2. - Attempting or assisting escape. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to attempt to escape or to assist in any way the escape of any person in the custody of any officer, or from any jail when confined therein, or from the custody of any guard or superintendent of the work detail, or from any place of confinement. 
(Code 1977, § 17-3) 
Sec. 58-3. - Missiles and firearms. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot any firearms or to throw or shoot, either by hand or with any bow, sling, flip or other instrument, any arrow, shot, bullet, stone or other missile at any location within the city except: 
(1)  By any law enforcement officer or animal control officer when acting within the scope of his duties; or 
(2)  By any patron at a licensed private shooting range; or 
(3)  By any participant in an authorized recreational event or practice held at a city park; or 
(4)  By any person on property for which a current hunting permit has been issued by the city as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 17-5; Ord. No. O-98-79, § 1, 11-16-98) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 42. 
Sec. 58-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2013-8, § 1, adopted Feb. 4, 2013, repealed § 58-4, which pertained to hunting and derived from Ord. No. O-98-79, § 2, adopted Nov. 16, 1998. 
Sec. 58-5. - Camping. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to camp anywhere in the city except at such places as may be designated by the mayor and council for that purpose. 
(Code 1977, § 17-9) 
Cross reference— Camping in parks, § 62-42. 
Sec. 58-6. - Disorderly conduct. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to do or commit any of the following: 
(1)  Use any obscene, vulgar or profane language; 
(2)  Behave in a rude, boisterous or violent manner; 
(3)  Engage in quarreling, fighting, or acting in a tumultuous or riotous manner; 
(4)  Commit any act tending to disturb the peace and quiet of the city; or 
(5)  Otherwise act in a disorderly manner. 
(Code 1977, § 17-11) 
Cross reference— Prohibited conduct in parks, § 62-38. 
State Law reference— Offenses against public order, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-30 et seq. 
Sec. 58-7. - Possession of marijuana unlawful; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess one ounce or less of marijuana within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  A person guilty of violating this section shall be punished in accordance with the city charter. 
(c)  The recorder shall exercise such jurisdiction and authority as provided by O.C.G.A. § 36-32-6. 
(Code 1977, § 17-14) 
State Law reference— Conditional discharge for possession of controlled substances as first offense, O.C.G.A. § 16-13-2. 
Sec. 58-8. - Entry on city reservoir property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or corporation to enter upon the city water reservoir or the surrounding property of the city for any purpose. City employees, officers and agents may enter upon the property to perform the duties of their employment. Other government officials may enter upon the property in carrying out their official duties. 
(Code 1977, § 17-15) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 86. 
Sec. 58-9. - Deposits on city reservoir property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or corporation to put, place or locate, or cause to be put, placed or located, any material of whatever kind or nature on the water reservoir property, either directly or indirectly, without the express permission of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 17-16) 
Sec. 58-10. - Pollution prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to discharge, or cause to be discharged, either directly or indirectly, into the water impounded in the city reservoir any waste matter, polluted materials or substances likely to cause pollution to such water, or any material likely to cause a degradation of the quality of the water in the reservoir. 
(Code 1977, § 17-17) 
Sec. 58-11. - Safety of public areas; loitering. 
(a)  No person shall remain or loiter upon any premises to which the public has access, including but not limited to such places as shopping center parking lots, where the person's presence upon such premises is unrelated to the normal activity, use or business for which such premises are made available to the public. 
(b)  No person shall consume alcoholic beverages, beer or wine upon any premises to which the public has access, including but not limited to such places as shopping center parking lots, where the person's presence upon such premises is unrelated to the normal activity, use or business for which such premises are made available to the public. 
(c)  No person shall deposit any garbage, refuse, rubbish, or litter which would constitute a danger to a pedestrian or a motor vehicle upon any premises to which the public has access, including but not limited to such places as shopping center parking lots, where the person's presence upon such premises is unrelated to the normal activity, use or business for which such premises are made available to the public. 
(d)  No person shall act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby any other person is placed in fear for the safety of his life, limb or health, or whereby the property of another is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged. 
(e)  No person shall endanger the lawful pursuits of another by acts of violence, angry threats or abusive conduct. 
(f)  No person shall cause, provoke or engage in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health or property of another. 
(g)  No person shall assemble or congregate with another or others for the purpose of causing, provoking or engaging in any fight or brawl. 
(h)  No person shall jostle, roughly crowd or push any person in any public place. 
(i)  No person shall use fighting words or loud and boisterous language directed towards another so as to create a breach of the peace potentially dangerous to the safety of person or property. 
(j)  No person shall congregate with another or others in or on any public way or place so as to halt or impede the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic after having been directed to clear such public way or place when ordered by the city police. 
(k)  For the purpose of this section, private parking facilities and associated walkways shall be considered a public way or place if such facilities are intended for use by the general public. 
(Code 1977, § 17-18) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 10; entertainment at pouring outlets, § 10-155; solid waste, ch. 70. 
Sec. 58-12. - Criminal trespass by motor vehicle. 
(a)  The city, pursuant to the authority of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-252(c), hereby adopts by reference the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-252(a), defining the offense of parking, standing or driving a vehicle in a private parking area after a request not to do so. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a monetary fine: 
(1)  Not to exceed $50.00 for the first such violation; 
(2)  Not to exceed $100.00 for the second such violation; and 
(3)  Not to exceed $150.00 for the third or subsequent such violation. 
(Code 1977, § 17-19) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 82. 
Sec. 58-13. - Limitations on discharge of phosphates. 
(a)  Declaration of policy. O.C.G.A. § 12-5-27.1 provides that whenever a local governmental entity is required by the environmental protection division to reduce phosphorus in its wastewater being discharged into the waters of the state, such local governmental entity shall pass an ordinance and/or resolution mandating the retail sale of low-phosphorus household laundry detergent as part of its phosphorus-reduction process. It is hereby declared to be the public policy of the authority, the city and the county to encourage the use of clean, phosphate-free household laundry detergents and to prohibit the sale of household laundry detergents which contain more than one-half percent phosphorus by weight. The authority, the city and the county find that such use and sale will be a cost-effective way to reduce the amount of phosphorus in wastewater discharge so as to protect the state's rivers and lakes downstream and promote the health, safety and welfare and to prevent injury to human health, plant and animal life and property. It is vital to the health, well-being and welfare of present and future inhabitants of the city and the county that these sources be protected against contamination and pollution. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Authority means the Douglasville-Douglas County water and Sewer Authority. 
City means the City of Douglasville, Georgia. 
County means Douglas County, Georgia. 
Household laundry detergent means a laundering cleaning compound in liquid, bar, spray, tablet, flake, powder or other form used for domestic clothes-cleaning purposes. The term household laundry detergent shall not mean: 
(1)  A dishwashing compound, household cleaner, metal cleaner, degreasing compound, commercial cleaner, industrial cleaner or other substance that is intended to be used for nonlaundry cleaning purposes; 
(2)  A detergent used in dairy, beverage or food-processing cleaning equipment; 
(3)  A phosphorus-acid product, including a sanitizer, brightener, acid cleaner or metal conditioner; 
(4)  A detergent used in hospitals, veterinary hospitals or clinics or health-care facilities or in agricultural production; 
(5)  A detergent used by industry for metal cleaning or conditioning; 
(6)  A detergent manufactured, stored or distributed for use or sale outside of the state; 
(7)  A detergent used in any laboratory, including a biological laboratory, research facility, chemical laboratory and engineering laboratory; or 
(8)  A detergent used in a commercial laundry that provides laundry service for hospitals, health-care facilities or veterinary hospitals. 
Person means any person, firm, partnership or corporation. 
Phosphorus means elemental phosphorus. 
(c)  Restricted use. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell at the retail level a household laundry detergent which contains greater than one-half percent phosphorus by weight and is intended to be used for domestic clothes-cleaning purposes. 
(d)  Penalties for violation. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $500.00 for each such violation. 
(e)  Compliance. In addition to the penalty provided in subsection (d) of this section, the authority, the city and the county may maintain an action or proceeding in any court of competent jurisdiction to compel compliance with or restrain any violation of this section. 
(f)  Right to damages. Nothing in this section shall be construed to abridge, limit or otherwise impair the right of any person to damages or other relief on account of injuries to persons or property arising out of a violation of this section and to maintain any action or other appropriate proceeding therefor. 
(g)  Severability. Should any subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this section be declared invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of this section in its entirety or any part hereof other than that so declared to be invalid. 
(Code 1977, § 17-20) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 86; sewers, § 86-71 et seq. 
Chapter 62 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-00-99, § 1, adopted Nov. 6, 2000, amended Art. I in it's entirety. Further, said ordinance repealed § 62-4 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 62-1. - Douglasville Parks and Recreation Advisory Board—Created, terms. 
There is hereby created the Douglasville Parks and Recreation Advisory Board. This board shall consist of 13 adult members over the age of 18, appointed by the mayor and city council. The post one member shall be a city resident of city election ward one at the time of his appointment. The post two member shall be a city resident of city election ward two at the time of his appointment. The post three member shall be a city resident of city election ward three at the time of his appointment. The post four member shall be a city resident of city election ward four at the time of his appointment. The post Five member shall be a city resident of city election ward five at the time of his appointment. The post six member shall be a city resident of city election ward two at the time of his appointment. The post seven member shall be a city resident of city election ward three at the time of his appointment. The post eight member shall be a Douglas County resident recommended by or chosen to represent the Cultural Art Council of Douglasville/ Douglas County Inc. The post nine through 13 members shall be Douglas County residents who are participants, parents of a minor participant, coaches, umpires or administrators for athletic teams which use city facilities as their home location. No appointed member shall lose eligibility to hold his post by reason of moving his residence during his term, but each individual must meet eligibility standards at the time of appointment and any reappointment. 
The members for posts one, four, seven, ten and 13 shall serve an initial term ending on February 15, 2022, with subsequent terms ending on the three-year anniversary of that date. The members for posts two, five, eight and 11 shall serve an initial term ending on February 15, 2021, with subsequent terms ending on the three-year anniversary of that date. The members for posts three, six, nine and 12 shall serve an initial term ending on February 15, 2020, with subsequent terms ending on the three-year anniversary of that date. 
(Ord. No. O-2019-1 , § 1, 1-14-19)

Sec. 62-2. - Same—Officers, rules and procedures, meetings. 
The advisory board shall elect officers from among its members and shall adopt rules and procedures for the conduct of its meetings. Meetings shall be held regularly and as specially set, shall be open to the public and shall be conducted in compliance with the Georgia Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. O-2019-1 , § 1, 1-14-19)

Sec. 62-3. - Same—Duties. 
The duties of the advisory board shall be to: 
(1)  Assist in the preparation of a periodic appraisal of the city's parks and recreation department's programs, services and facilities. 
(2)  Monitor and identify the community's needs for parks and recreation services and facilities. 
(3)  Make recommendations to the city council regarding the planning and functioning of the parks and recreation department through the parks and recreation department director and the city manager. 
(4)  Resolve any disputes within the youth athletic associations brought before the advisory board. 
(5)  Support the recreation department in the enforcement of youth coaches certification and criminal background checks. 
(Ord. No. O-2019-1 , § 1, 1-14-19)

ARTICLE II. - USE OF PUBLIC PARKS AND FACILITIES GENERALLY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2013-11, § 1, adopted March 4, 2013, amended Art. II title to read as herein set out. Former Art. II title pertained to use of public parks and facilities. 

Sec. 62-36. - Violation, penalty. 
Any violation of this article shall be deemed a violation punishable as prescribed by the charter of the City of Douglasville. 
(Code 1977, § 17½-22) 
Charter reference— General penalty, § 6.03. 
Sec. 62-37. - Use of grounds and facilities in general. 
Each person, firm or corporation using the public parks and grounds shall clean up all debris, extinguish all fires when such fires are permitted, and leave the premises in good order and the facilities in a neat and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1977, § 17½-16) 
Sec. 62-38. - Prohibited acts. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation using public parks, grounds or facilities to either perform or permit to be performed any of the following acts: 
(1)  Willfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with or displace or remove any buildings; bridges; tables; benches; fireplaces; railings; paving or paving material; waterlines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof; signs, notices or placards, whether temporary or permanent; monuments; stakes, posts or other boundary markers; or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(2)  Throw, discharge or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or other body of water in or adjacent to any park or any tributary, stream, storm sewer or drain flowing into such waters any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of such waters. 
(3)  Damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree or plant or any part thereof. 
(4)  Hunt, molest, harm, frighten, kill, trap, chase, tease, shoot or throw missiles at any animal, reptile or bird; or remove or have in his possession the young of any wild animal, or the eggs, nest or young of any other animal. 
(5)  Bring in or dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage, refuse or other trash. No such refuse or trash shall be placed in any waters in or contiguous to any park or left anywhere on the grounds thereof but shall be placed in the proper receptacles where these are provided; and where receptacles are not so provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for the presence of same and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(6)  Disturb the peace or use any profane or obscene language. 
(7)  Endanger the safety of any person by any conduct or act. 
(8)  Engage in fighting. 
(9)  Carry, possess or drink any alcoholic beverage, except at the West Pines Golf Course. 
(10)  Violate any rule for the use of a park made or approved by the parks and recreation board. 
(11)  Prevent any person from using any park, or any of its facilities, or interfere with such use in compliance with this chapter and with the rules applicable to such use. 
(12)  Swim, bathe or wade in any waters or waterways in or adjacent to any park except in such waters and at such places as are provided therefor and in compliance with such regulations as may be adopted therefor. 
(13)  Dress or undress on any beach or in any vehicle, toilet or other place except in such bathing houses or structures as may be provided for that purpose. 
(14)  Smoke, inhale, exhale, or carry any lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, weed or plant in any manner or in any form, except outdoors at the West Pines Golf Course. 
(Code 1977, § 17½-17; Ord. No. O-05-25, § 2, 6-6-05; Ord. No. O-2012-33, §§ 1, 2, 7-2-12) 
Cross reference— Disorderly conduct, § 58-6. 
Sec. 62-39. - Hours of operation. 
The public parks shall be open daily to the public during the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m.; and it shall be unlawful for any person or persons other than city or county personnel conducting city or county business therein to occupy or be present in such parks during any other hours. Any section or part of a park, or an entire park, may be declared closed to the public by the director of parks and recreation at any time and for any interval of time, either temporarily or at regular or stated intervals. 
(Code 1977, § 17½-18) 
Sec. 62-40. - Group activity. 
(a)  Whenever more than ten members of any group, association or organization desire to use any park facilities for a particular purpose, such as picnics, parties or theatrical or other entertainment performances, a representative of such group, association or organization shall first obtain a permit from the director of parks and recreation for such purpose. 
(b)  The director of parks and recreation shall grant the application for a permit if it appears that the group, association or organization will not interfere with the general use of the park by individual members of the public and if the group, association or organization meets all other reasonable conditions which may be imposed by the director of parks and recreation. 
(c)  Such application may contain a requirement for an indemnity bond to protect the city or county from any liability of any kind or character and to protect city or county property from damage. 
(Code 1977, § 17½-19) 
Sec. 62-41. - Use of picnic areas. 
No person in a park shall use any portion of the picnic areas, or of any of the buildings or structures therein, for the purpose of holding picnics to the exclusion of other persons, nor shall any person use such areas and facilities for an unreasonable time if the facilities are crowded unless permitted by the director of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1977, § 17½-20) 
Sec. 62-42. - General regulations. 
(a)  Games. It shall be unlawful for any person to take part in or abet the playing of any games involving thrown or otherwise propelled objects such as balls, stones, arrows, javelins or model airplanes except in areas set apart for such forms of recreation. The playing of rough or potentially dangerous games such as football, baseball and soccer is prohibited except on the fields, courts or areas provided therefor. 
(b)  Camping. It shall be unlawful for any person to set up tents, shacks or any other temporary shelter for the purpose of overnight camping, nor shall any person leave in a park after closing hours any movable structure or special vehicle to be used, or that could be used, for such purpose, such as a house trailer, camp trailer, camp wagon or the like unless permitted by the director of parks and recreation. 
(c)  Fires. It shall be unlawful for any person to build or attempt to build a fire except in such areas and under such regulations as may be designated by the director of parks and recreation. No person shall drop, throw or otherwise scatter lighted matches, burning cigarettes or cigars, tobacco paper or other flammable material within any park area or on a highway, road or street abutting or contiguous thereto. 
(d)  Animals. It shall be unlawful to bring any dangerous animal into any park; and it shall be unlawful to permit any dog to be in any park. 
(e)  Motor vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle within any area of a public park, playground or recreational facility if operation within such an area is prohibited by any clearly posted sign or notice in such area erected under the authority of the director of parks and recreation or the mayor and council. 
(f)  Sales. It shall be unlawful for any person to vend, sell, peddle or offer for sale any commodity or article within any park unless permitted by the director of parks and recreation. 
(g)  Alcoholic beverages. It shall be unlawful for any person within any park to have in his possession, custody or control any alcoholic beverage of any kind whatsoever, except at the West Pines Golf Course. 
(h)  Signs. It shall be unlawful for anyone to paste, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement or inscription whatever upon and within public parks or playgrounds and recreational facilities unless same is permitted by the director of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1977, § 17½-21; Ord. No. O-96-50, §§ 1, 2, 10-21-96; Ord. No. O-05-40, § 1, 7-5-05; Ord. No. O-2012-33, § 3, 7-2-12) 
Secs. 62-43—62-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - USE OF ATHLETIC FIELDS 

Sec. 62-51. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Affiliated sports association means a sports association which is a member and participant in a national, state-wide or regional sports competition league. 
Athletic field means any of the fields used for softball, baseball, soccer or football at any city park. 
Coach means a teacher or manager for a sports team, working with a team for an entire athletic season or other indefinite period of time, with authority to interact with players or to come onto the athletic field or sidelines before, during or after a game, practice or tournament. 
Director means the City of Douglasville Director of Parks and Recreation or his designee. 
Health care provider means a licensed physician or another licensed individual under the supervision of a licensed physician, such as a nurse practitioner, physician assistant, or certified athletic trainer who has received training in concussion evaluation and management. 
Instructor means a teacher for a sports team, working with a team for a limited period of time less than an entire athletic season, with authority to interact with players or to come onto the athletic field or sidelines before, during or after a game, practice or tournament. 
Sports association means any individual or legally constituted entity which organizes and operates one or more competitive amateur sports teams for which the home team members are primarily local residents, and having a usual predetermined competition season and competition schedule. 
Youth means a person or persons under the age of 19 years. 
Youth athletic activity means an organized athletic activity in which the majority of the participants are youth athletes and are engaging in an organized athletic game or competition against another team, club, or entity or in practice or preparation for an organized game or competition against another team, club, or entity, and renting an athletic field or using an athletic field as the home team. 
Youth sports association means any sports association having a majority of participants who are youths. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-11, § 2, 3-4-13; Ord. No. O-2014-24, §§ 1, 2, 4-21-14; Ord. No. O-2015-40, §§ 1, 2 , 9-8-15; Ord. No. O-2017-23 , § 1, 5-15-17) 
Sec. 62-52. - Regulations. 
(a)  Athletic fields may be reserved on a reasonable schedule for use by sports associations for competition, practice and tournaments. Any youth sports association which is a non-profit corporation shall apply for reservation at least 60 days in advance of the first proposed date for use of the athletic field, to allow adequate time for processing, and to assure proper consideration of the preference criteria stated in subsection (d); provided however, that the director may waive compliance with this requirement for good cause shown, where the subject field has not already been reserved by another applicant for the requested time period. 
(b)  Whenever an athletic field is not in use pursuant to reservation by a sports association, the director may in his discretion make that athletic field available for use by the public. 
(c)  All reservations of athletic fields shall be initiated by written application filed with the director on forms prescribed by the director. At a minimum, such application shall disclose the following: 
(1)  The legal name of the applicant, including the names of the sports association's principals, their addresses, and their telephone numbers; 
(2)  A proposed schedule for games and practices and tournaments, including make-up days, and a schedule showing times when field lights will be needed; 
(3)  Age groups for each team; 
(4)  Program registration information including registration dates, times, locations, fees, and the length of the season; 
(5)  A copy of the sports association's registration procedures, and try-out procedures, including a nondiscrimination statement substantially as follows: 
This association agrees that all persons shall be offered the opportunity to participate in all association programs regardless of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, handicap, or other non-merit factors. 
(6)  A financial statement for a minimum 12-month period concluding after the end of the last previous sports season, showing the name, address and phone number for the sports association's treasurer, along with one or more bank statements showing the funds on hand; 
(7)  A copy of the sports association's insurance binder showing not less than $1,000,000.00 in liability coverage with the city as an additional loss payee, and showing a provision requiring notification to the city if the policy is cancelled prior to expiration; and 
(8)  The names and completed consent forms for background check by the director and the City of Douglasville. 
(9)  If the sports association is a youth sports association, a full statement of all fees and charges to be paid to the youth sports association by any youth athlete member or his parents or legal guardian for participation in the youth sports association during the athletic season for which the athletic field will be rented, including but not limited to fees for uniforms, equipment, field rental, concessions, food and drinks, umpire fees, coaching fees, transportation, vending, advertising, copy costs and any other administrative charges. This statement may be amended in writing after submission to add further fees and charges, but new fees and charges shall not be implemented until filed with the director. 
(d)  The Douglas County Soccer Association, Inc. or its successor shall have priority to reserve the Fowler Field soccer facilities, pursuant to application. Youth sports shall have priority over adult sports. Affiliated sports associations shall have priority over unaffiliated sports associations. In all other cases where there are multiple applications for reservation of an athletic field for one time period, the director shall grant an application and award a reservation of the athletic field to one sports association per time period in his discretion based on the following criteria: 
(1)  Full use of the athletic field by the applicant during the immediately previous season for that sport; 
(2)  Past compliance with city laws, rules and regulations for use of parks and athletic fields by that sports association, including sportsmanlike conduct of all officials and players; 
(3)  Whether the proposed use of the athletic field is consistent with the intended and designed use for that athletic field; 
(4)  Ability and likelihood of the local public to join a team and participate in the proposed use based on factors including cost of participation, uniform cost, travel schedule and local schedule; 
(5)  Whether the proposed use of the athletic field is one already adequately provided to the community by another sports association with an existing reservation; 
(6)  Financial solvency and transparency of the applicant; and 
(7)  Ability of the sports association to provide sports programming that will meet the recreational needs of the local community. 
(e)  For pre-season practices, reservations shall not exceed three 90-minute practice sessions in any one calendar week; for practices during the playing season, reservations shall not exceed two 90-minute practice sessions in any one calendar week. A sports association shall have adults present to supervise all youth activities, from the time the first youth arrives until the last one departs. 
(f)  City parks close at 11:00 p.m. No one shall use an athletic field without an approved reservation, unless the gate is unlocked by the city indicating that the athletic field is open for public use. 
(g)  The property and cleaning deposit amounts for use of athletic fields shall be $250.00 per reservation or athletic season. The fee for use of a concession stand or storage building shall be $250.00 per reservation or athletic season. The fee amounts for use of athletic fields shall be as follows: 
(1)  For Fowler Field: 
a.  One thousand six hundred twenty dollars per year for up to 27 weeks for an affiliated sports association, including use of field lights; or 
b.  One hundred fifty dollars for up to six hours in one day for an unaffiliated sports association, plus $20.00 per hour for use of field lights as needed. 
(2)  For any football field: 
a.  One thousand four hundred eighty-five dollars per year for up to nine weeks for an affiliated sports association; or 
b.  One hundred fifty dollars for up to six hours in one day for an unaffiliated sports association, plus $20.00 per hour for use of field lights as needed. 
(3)  For any softball or baseball field: $125.00 per day per field or $75.00 for four hours per field; plus $20.00 per hour for use of field lights per field as needed. 
(h)  No one shall operate or enter the concession stands or storage buildings at an athletic field without express prior permission of the director. Storage of concession items at times when not open sales requires the written permission of the director. 
(i)  No one shall host or participate in a sports tournament at a city park without an approved reservation including a schedule for a tournament. 
(j)  No person or sports association shall restrict or interfere with any other activity at the park or the facility taking place off the boundaries of the athletic field reserved. 
(k)  The director may cancel any scheduled activity on any reserved athletic field due to severe weather when the director determines that such use would cause harm to the participants or damage to the athletic field. 
(l)  After each reserved use of an athletic field, the reserving sports association shall remove any litter and garbage from the athletic field and the surrounding area, including any dugouts or team areas, any concession areas used, and any bleachers adjacent to the athletic field. The director is authorized to withhold any clean-up deposit due to failure of a sports association to comply with this provision. 
(m)  No one shall construct any new fixed component, or repair, renovate, change, or relocate any fixed component of any city park without express written permission from the director. No one shall leave a privately owned storage vessel, trailer or building in a city park after same-day open hours for that park, without the prior written permission of the director. 
(n)  No one shall place a lock upon any city building, concession stand, gate or facility without the prior written permission of the director. When such permission is granted, the association shall furnish to the director a tagged key for each lock, prior to use of the lock. 
(o)  No individual shall serve as a coach, instructor or team parent for a sports association reserving an athletic field for youth sports who is not approved by the director. A criminal background check by the city and approval of the director is required before any individual may serve as a youth coach, instructor, or team parent for an affiliated sports association in connection with use of an athletic field. This requirement shall not apply to any coach, instructor or team parent for an event where a sports promoter has reserved the athletic field. 
(p)  Every sports association reserving an athletic field shall supply to the director, in advance of the first reserve date for any sports season, a complete roster of players, including the name, age and residence address for each player. This roster shall be updated and supplied to the director within 30 days of the addition of any new player. 
(q)  Every sports association reserving an athletic field shall supply to the director, in advance of the first reserve date for any sports season, a complete roster of coaches and instructors for the sports association. This roster shall be updated and supplied to the director prior to the use of any new coach or instructor in connection with an athletic field. 
(r)  After approval of a reservation, the director may revoke or terminate the reservation based any of the following: 
(1)  Persistent damage to city park facilities while in use by the sports association; 
(2)  Disorderly behavior and unbecoming conduct by any player, coach or instructor of the sports association occurring in connection with use of an athletic field; 
(3)  Noncompliance with or disobedience of any city ordinance or rule concerning city parks and recreation; or 
(4)  Failure to use the athletic field as approved or for significant periods of the reserved time, where failure is not due to inclement weather. 
(s)  Youth coaches, instructors and team parents requiring the criminal background check must wear a current city issued identification card, that indicates both criteria have been met, at all times while serving either of those roles at an athletic field. The minimum fine for violation of this provision shall be $50.00. 
(t)  Youth sports associations, their coaches, personnel and youths shall comply with the following protocol: 
(1)  Prior to the beginning of each athletic season of a youth athletic activity, every youth athletic association shall provide an information sheet to all youth athletes' parents or legal guardians which informs them of the nature and risk of concussion and head injury; 
(2)  If a youth athlete participating in a youth athletic activity exhibits symptoms of having a concussion, the youth sports association shall remove that athlete from the game, competition, tryout, or practice, and advise the youth's athletes' parents or legal guardians that the youth athlete must be evaluated by a health care provider for concussion before returning to play; and 
(3)  If a youth athlete is deemed by a health care provider to have sustained a concussion, the coach and youth sports association shall not permit the youth athlete to return to play until the youth athlete receives clearance from a health care provider for a full or graduated return to play; and 
(4)  This subsection (t) shall not create any liability for, or create a cause of action against, a the city or its insurers, agents, officers, employees, volunteers, other city personnel for any act or omission to act related to the removal or non-removal of a youth athlete from a game, competition, tryout, or practice pursuant to this subsection. This subsection (t) shall not create any liability for, or create a cause of action against any health care providers acting in a volunteer capacity for any act or omission to act related to the removal or non-removal of a youth athlete from a game, competition, tryout, or practice pursuant to this subsection. 
(u)  No youth sports association shall request or require any youth member or his parents or legal guardians to pay fees or charges other than those shown in the statement of fees or an amended statement of fees required by paragraph (c)(9) above. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-11, §§ 2, 4, 3-4-13; Ord. No. O-2013-39, § 1, 9-16-13; Ord. No. O-2014-24, §§ 3—5, 4-21-14; Ord. No. O-2015-40, §§ 3, 4 , 9-8-15; Ord. No. O-2017-23 , §§ 2, 3, 5-15-17) 
Chapter 70 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to provide for collection, disposal of garbage, rubbish and refuse, § 1.03(j). 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; environment, ch. 38; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 54; safety of public areas, § 58-11; utilities, ch. 86. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ashes means the waste products of coal and other fuel used for heating and cooking from all public and private establishments and from all residences. 
Commercial container means a solid waste container supplied for continuing use to a commercial or industrial establishment or to an apartment complex, or a container supplied for temporary use at a construction site, including but not limited to all dumpsters, commercial compactor units, and commercial roll-off containers. 
Garbage means all putrescible wastes, except sewage and body wastes, including vegetable and animal offal and carcasses of dead animals, but excluding recognized industrial by-products, and includes all refuse or accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter, liquid or otherwise, that attends the preparation, use, cooking, consumption, merchandising or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruits or vegetables. 
Health officer means a representative of the county health department. 
Refuse means garbage, rubbish, ashes and other putrescible and nonputrescible wastes, except sewage, from all public and private establishments and residences. 
Residential container means a solid waste container supplied for continuing use to premises used primarily for residential purposes. 
Trash means all nonputrescible wastes, except ashes, from all public and private establishments and from all residences. 
(Code 1977, § 12-1; Ord. No. O-95-20, § 1, 7-17-95) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 70-2—70-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION REGULATIONS 

Sec. 70-36. - Authority of city. 
The mayor and council may provide for the collection and disposal of garbage, trash and refuse, regulate the manner and time of such collection and disposal, establish the rates to be charged therefor, and otherwise make such rules and regulations pertaining to garbage, trash and refuse as may be desirable to assure the public health and welfare. 
(Code 1977, § 12-17) 
Sec. 70-37. - Disposal generally. 
All garbage accumulating in private houses or on private premises, in hotels, restaurants, boardinghouses, fruit stands, stores, markets or elsewhere in the city shall be carried to a place designated and approved by the mayor and council. Such garbage as melon rinds, fruit parings, vegetables, leavings and liquid waste used as food or drink for fowl or animals may be kept on the premises temporarily, from one hauling period to the next, in such a manner as not to cause a nuisance or become a fly-attracting agent. 
(Code 1977, § 12-18) 
Sec. 70-38. - Accumulation prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or lessee of any building, yard or lot of ground within the city to allow garbage, trash or refuse of any kind to accumulate or remain in the building, or upon the yard or lot, unless placed in a container as required by this article. 
(Code 1977, § 12-19) 
Sec. 70-39. - Containers—Required. 
Every person and every business or commercial enterprise in the corporate limits of the city having vegetable or animal waste or other garbage shall keep the same on the premises in one or more containers at places where it may be conveniently reached and collected by the sanitary department of the city. Additionally every person shall affix a sign in a conspicuous location on each container (other than those exclusively for single-family residential use) prohibiting private dumping. 
(Code 1977, § 12-20; Ord. No. O-05-50, § 4, 9-19-05) 
Sec. 70-40. - Same—Specifications. 
Containers for the accumulation of garbage and refuse shall meet such specifications therefor as promulgated by the mayor and council and on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 12-21) 
Sec. 70-41. - Fees. 
The fees for the collection and disposal of garbage and refuse shall be as determined by the mayor and council from time to time and on file in the office of the finance director. Except as specifically exempted under this section, the owner, occupant, tenant or lessee of any home, building or commercial structure shall pay at least the minimum charge for garbage pick-up and disposal, as adopted by the mayor and council and on file with the finance director. Any single-family household in which any adult resident is over the age of 64 years shall be eligible for exemption from payment of the minimum charge for residential collection and disposal of garbage and refuse, upon written certification of the same to the finance director by the owner, occupant, tenant or lessee thereof. Fees for solid waste containers and services shall be incurred exclusively in the name(s) or the owner(s) and/or lessee(s) of the subject property, and not in the name(s) of any contractor(s) performing work upon the property. 
(Code 1977, § 12-23; Ord. No. O-96-26, § 1, 5-6-96; Ord. No. O-01-81, § 8, 12-3-01; Ord. No. O-05-29, § 1, 6-20-05; Ord. No. O-07-32, § 1, 6-4-07) 
Cross reference— Failure to pay utility charges, § 86-46. 
Sec. 70-42. - Maintenance of containers. 
Every garbage and trash container required by this article shall be maintained in as sanitary a condition as possible in view of the use to which it is put, and shall be thoroughly cleansed as needed by washing, sterilizing or otherwise. 
(Code 1977, § 12-24) 
Sec. 70-43. - Notice of damage to commercial containers. 
It shall be the duty of every person owning, controlling, managing, operating, policing, renting, or occupying any premises to which a commercial container is supplied to inspect the container regularly and to give notice to the city of any container which has jagged edges capable of causing injuries or which has deteriorated or been damaged to such an extent. 
(Code 1977, § 12-25; Ord. No. O-95-20, § 2, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 70-44. - Commercial containers furnished by city. 
(a)  The city will determine the size of each container needed by the user and such containers shall be placed in a manner as to be easily accessible to the city equipment making the pick-up. It shall be the responsibility of the user to remove all or any vehicles or objects blocking the container. 
(b)  The containers provided the user shall not be damaged or abused by the user. If such containers are damaged or abused by the user or its employees, the user shall be responsible for the expenses incurred by the city in repairing and/or replacing such container. 
(c)  No person shall ignite or set fire to the contents of any waste container provided by the city. Any person violating this provision of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-3 of this Code. 
(d)  No person shall dispose of residential waste or refuse in a commercial container. No person shall place into any commercial container any waste or refuse not generated by the established to which the container is supplied. 
(e)  No person shall place into any commercial container any material which is highly acidic, radioactive, volatile, highly flammable, explosive toxic, hazardous or any material which is hazardous, damaged or dangerous waste as defined by federal, state or local law, regulation or ordinance. 
(Code 1977, § 12-26; Ord. No. O-91-24, § 2, 8-5-91; Ord. No. O-95-20, § 3, 7-17-95) 
Sec. 70-45. - Cover required for vehicles hauling garbage, etc. 
All vehicles used in hauling garbage, trash or refuse of any kind whatsoever on any street or highway within the city shall have beds of tight construction to prevent the contents from falling or sifting onto the street, highway or ground, and shall at all times, except when loading or unloading, be covered with a canvas cover or some comparable cover. 
(Code 1977, § 12-27) 
Sec. 70-46. - Duty of customer to bag leaves and other common yard wastes. 
(a)  All leaves, small limbs, twigs, clippings, straw, bark, pine cones, grass and other such materials associated with common yard waste shall be properly bagged in an appropriate container in order for it to be disposed of by the city's trash disposal service. 
(b)  Plastic containers of sufficient size and strength of the generic term lawn bags or yard bags shall be utilized for the purpose of disposal of such waste. Bags shall be of such size as to allow the openings to be securely fastened so that no spillage shall occur upon loading or transporting by city employees. Bags shall be of sufficient strength not to split, open or tear under the load of the contents while being picked up, carried by the slack in the top of the bag or loaded onto the truck. Spillages due to improper bagging techniques or materials shall not be the responsibility of the city or its employees. 
(c)  No container shall be placed upon the paved or traveled portion of a city street or sidewalk while awaiting collection. 
(Code 1977, § 12-28) 
Sec. 70-47. - Residential containers furnished by city. 
(a)  The city shall furnish residential containers to all residential properties in the City of Douglasville. 
(b)  The containers shall be the property of the City of Douglasville and shall not be used for any purposes not approved by the city. 
(c)  The container shall not be damaged or abused by the user. If a container is damaged or destroyed, the property owner and tenant shall be jointly and severably liable to the city for the cost of repair or replacement of the container. 
(d)  It shall be the responsibility of the user to place the container at the curb at the time specified by the city for garbage pick-up and to remove the container promptly after the city has emptied the container. 
(e)  The container lid shall be securely closed at all times except when the container is being filled or emptied to keep out animals and insects. 
(f)  No person shall ignite or set fire to the contents of any residential container provided by the city. Any person violating this provision of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-3 of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 12-29) 
Sec. 70-48. - Reserved. 
Sec. 70-49. - Authorized residential containers; required. 
(a)  Every person disposing of household trash or garbage at any residence (other than apartment residences) within the corporate limits of the City of Douglasville shall do so by enclosing all such household trash or garbage within one or more authorized residential containers supplied by the city or its franchisee, with the lid(s) fully and securely closed. The following described household waste shall be exempt from this requirement: 
(1)  All leaves, small limbs, twigs, plant clippings, straw, bark, pine cones, grass, and other common yard waste, which may be disposed of in non-authorized bags without city stickers and in non-authorized containers as provided in section 70-46; and 
(2)  Recyclable materials as authorized by the mayor and council and on file with the city clerk; and 
(3)  Household trash or garbage when disposed of in a bag upon which an authorized city sticker has been affixed, provided that such bag is strong enough to contain the contents throughout the disposal process; and 
(4)  Any solid waste disposed pursuant to an exempt "community clean-up" program authorized by city resolution. 
(b)  The city sanitation department shall assign an appropriate sized residential container for each household, considering, among other factors, the following: the request of the resident(s), the usual volume of waste generated by the household, the frequency with which waste is disposed of in bags which have or should have city stickers affixed, any history of non-compliance with this article, and availability of city containers in specific sizes. Where the city sanitation department determines that any assigned container size is inadequate for any household, the department may assign a different size container more appropriate to the needs of the residents, and the resident shall pay the lawful rate for the newly assigned container. 
(Ord. No. O-95-12, § 1, 5-15-95; Ord. No. O-97-36, § 1, 4-21-97; Ord. No. O-98-42, § 1, 5-18-98; Ord. No. O-05-29, § 2, 6-20-05) 
Sec. 70-50. - Uncollected residential waste. 
The city sanitation department or its authorized franchisee may decline to collect household waste which is left at the curb for disposal not in compliance with section 70-49. Failure of the resident(s) to remove from the curb any rejected household waste within 48 hours of the regular collection time shall constitute unlawful accumulation. 
(Ord. No. O-95-12, § 1, 5-15-95; Ord. No. O-05-29, § 3, 6-20-05) 
Sec. 70-51. - City stickers not for resale or counterfeit. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or business enterprise, other than the City of Douglasville or its authorized franchisees, to transfer or offer to transfer, within the corporate limits of the City of Douglasville, any specially marked solid waste bag sticker authorized by the city for use in connection with disposal of household trash or garbage. It shall be unlawful for any person or business enterprise other than the City of Douglasville or its authorized franchisees to fabricate or to transfer within the corporate limits of the City of Douglasville any sticker substantially similar in appearance to any specially marked solid waste bag sticker authorized by the city for use in connection with disposal of household trash or garbage. 
(Ord. No. O-05-29, § 4, 6-20-05) 
Secs. 70-52—70-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PERMIT FOR PRIVATE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-97-59, § 1, adopted Sept. 2, 1997, repealed Art. III, §§ 70-76—70-82 and enacted a new Art. III, §§ 70-76—70-83, to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 70-76. - Required. 
No person, firm or corporation except the duly authorized franchisee or duly authorized agents or employees of the city, shall collect garbage or trash within the city or convey or transport garbage or trash on the streets, alleys, and public thoroughfares of the city for profit. 
(Ord. No. O-97-59, § 1, 9-2-97) 
Sec. 70-77. - Filing application; investigation. 
Any person, firm or corporation desiring a permit for the collection, removal and disposal of garbage, trash and rubbish shall make application for such permit to the city council, which shall make or cause to be made such investigation as it may consider necessary in order to determine whether or not the public convenience and necessity require the granting of such permit, and whether the applicant is a fit and proper person to conduct such business or activity for profit. 
(Ord. No. O-97-59, § 1, 9-2-97) 
Sec. 70-78. - Contents of application. 
The application for a private collection and disposal permit shall set forth: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  Whether the applicant is an individual, a corporation or a partnership; 
(3)  The trade name under which the applicant does or proposes to do business; 
(4)  The number of vehicles the applicant desires to operate; 
(5)  The class, size and design of each vehicle; 
(6)  The names, addresses, and drivers license numbers of all drivers and other information sufficient to obtain driving record reports on each driver; 
(7)  Whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude; 
(8)  Sufficient information for the city to obtain a commercial credit report; 
(9)  Proof of public liability insurance to cover the operation of his vehicles for damage to property of others while operating such vehicles on the streets of this city; 
(10)  The nature and character of the service the applicant proposes to render; 
(11)  The experience he or it has had in rendering such service; 
(12)  The patrons for whom he proposes to render this service; and 
(13)  Such other information as the mayor and city council may require. 
(Ord. No. O-97-59, § 1, 9-2-97) 
Sec. 70-79. - Fees. 
(a)  Application. The mayor and city council shall determine by resolution the amount to be charged as an application fee to cover the cost of the investigation. Such fee shall not be refundable. 
(b)  Permit. The mayor and city council shall determine by resolution the amount to be charged as a permit fee. Such permit fee shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, applicable business license fees and taxes. 
(Ord. No. O-97-59, § 1, 9-2-97) 
Sec. 70-80. - Insurance required. 
Any applicant making application for a permit under this section shall, for each and every vehicle to be used in collection, have issued to him and maintained by him by a company duly licensed to operate and do business in the state, a policy of indemnity insurance in the amount of at least $500,000.00 for bodily injury to any one person, in the amount of $1,000,000.00 for injuries to more than one person sustained in the same accident, and in the amount of $300,000.00 for property damage resulting from any one accident. Such policy of indemnity may cover all of the vehicles operated by the same owner. A copy of such policy shall be furnished to the city upon application for a permit, and a copy shall be thereafter maintained with the city clerk should a permit be granted. 
(Ord. No. O-97-59, § 1, 9-2-97) 
Sec. 70-81. - Nontransferable; revocation. 
All permits granted by the mayor and city council for collection, removal and disposal of garbage, trash and rubbish shall be nontransferable. Such permits may be revoked for a violation of this article by the city council at any time when, in its judgment, such action is deemed to be in the best interest of the public. The permit holder shall receive five days advance notice of the revocation and may request a hearing before the mayor and council to protest the revocation. 
(Ord. No. O-97-59, § 1, 9-2-97) 
Sec. 70-82. - Display; inspection. 
In all cases where permits have been issued for the collection, removal and disposal of garbage, trash and rubbish, each such permit shall be in the possession of the person rendering such service, and shall be subject to inspection at all times, and the permit numbers shall be painted on both sides of the vehicle used for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. O-97-59, § 1, 9-2-97) 
Sec. 70-83. - Penalty for violation; parties to a violation. 
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be held liable and punished as provided in Section 4.13 of the Douglasville City Charter. Any person who hires another to collect, remove or dispose of garbage, trash or rubbish within the city shall first inspect the hauler's permit and verify that the same has been duly issued by the city clerk and that the same is current and effective; failure to comply with this provision shall constitute a violation of this chapter. Any person who intentionally aids, abets, advises, encourages, hires, counsels or procures another to commit a violation of this chapter is a party to said violation, notwithstanding that the person alleged to have directly committed the violation has not been prosecuted or convicted, has been convicted of a different violation, or is not amenable to justice or has been acquitted. 
(Ord. No. O-97-59, § 1, 9-2-97; Ord. No. O-01-41, § 9, 6-18-01) 
Secs. 70-84—70-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LITTER CONTROL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Vehicles dropping loads upon roadway, § 82-10. 

Sec. 70-101. - Short title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as the Douglasville Anti-Litter Ordinance. 
(Code 1977, § 14-51) 
Sec. 70-102. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Aircraft means any contrivance used or designated for navigation or for flight in the air. The word aircraft shall include helicopters and lighter-than-air dirigibles and balloons. 
Authorized private receptacle means a litter storage and collection receptacle as required and authorized in the ordinances of the city. 
City means the City of Douglasville. 
Commercial handbill means any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature: 
(1)  Which advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity or thing; 
(2)  Which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; 
(3)  Which directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit; but the terms of this clause shall not apply where an admission fee is charged or a collection is taken up for the purpose of defraying the expenses incident to such meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, when either of the same is held, given or takes place in connection with the dissemination of information which is not restricted under the ordinary rules of decency, good morals, public peace, safety and good order; provided, that nothing contained in this clause shall be deemed to authorize the holding, giving or taking place of any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, without a license, where such license is or may be required by any law of this state, or under any ordinance of this city; or 
(4)  Which, while containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is predominantly and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
Litter means garbage, refuse, and rubbish and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare, and the term also includes materials of whatever nature which, although not waste or discarded material, have been placed on or scattered onto the property of another without permission and are not promptly removed. 
Newspaper means any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the United States Postal Service, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law; and, in addition thereto, means and includes any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year, and sold to the public. 
Noncommercial handbill means any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature not included in a commercial handbill or newspaper. 
Park means a park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other public area in the city, owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
Private premises means any dwelling, house, building or other structure, designed or used either wholly or in part for residential or commercial purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
Public place means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes, except body wastes, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, and solid market and industrial wastes. 
Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, natural fibers, man-made materials and similar materials. 
Vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1977, § 14-52) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-103. - Penalties. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be punished in accordance with section 1-3. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Code 1977, § 14-72) 
Sec. 70-104. - Duty of business owners, occupants to prevent littering. 
(a)  Generally. The owner or occupant of any store or other place of business situated within the city shall exercise reasonable diligence at all times to keep his premises clean of wastepaper, wrapping paper, paper napkins, cartons, package containers and other used or waste materials thrown or left on the premises by customers of such business, and to take reasonable measures to prevent the same from drifting or blowing to adjoining premises. 
(b)  Receptacles. Receptacles of sufficient size and number shall be placed on the premises accessible to the customers of any business where the articles of waste referred to in subsection (a) of this section may be disposed of. 
(c)  Signs. Each and every business establishment shall place upon its premises in conspicuous places in close proximity to the receptacles required by subsection (b) of this section signs which shall, in essence, convey to its customers a request that they use such receptacles for the disposal of waste material. 
(Code 1977, § 12-4) 
Sec. 70-105. - Duty of customer to use litter receptacles. 
It shall be unlawful for any customer going upon the premises of another in any manner to dispose of wastepaper, wrapping paper, paper napkins, cartons, package containers and other used or waste materials, except in receptacles provided for such purposes. 
(Code 1977, § 12-5) 
Sec. 70-106. - Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. 
Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1977, § 14-54) 
Sec. 70-107. - Sweeping litter into gutters prohibited. 
No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
(Code 1977, § 14-55) 
Sec. 70-108. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-06-51, § 2, adopted Dec. 4, 2006, repealed § 70-108, which pertained to a merchant's duty to keep sidewalks free of litter and derived from Code 1977, § 14-56. 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. 
Sec. 70-109. - Truck loads causing litter. 
No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed, loaded or covered as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or other public place, mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter of any kind. 
(Code 1977, § 14-58) 
Sec. 70-110. - Dropping litter from aircraft. 
No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the city any litter, handbill or any other object. 
(Code 1977, § 14-66) 
Sec. 70-111. - Posting notices prohibited. 
No person shall post or affix any notice, poster or other paper or device, calculated to attract the attention of the public, to any lamp post, public utility pole or shade tree within the right-of-way of any street, or upon any private property without the permission of the owner or occupant, or upon any public structure, building or property, except as may be authorized or required by law. 
(Code 1977, § 14-67) 
Sec. 70-112. - Owner to maintain premises free of litter. 
The owner and/or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter. Provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection. 
(Code 1977, § 14-69) 
Sec. 70-113. - Clearing of litter from open private property by city. 
(a)  Notice to remove. The building official, health officer, city clerk, or chief of police, or their deputies, are hereby authorized and empowered to notify the owner of property within the city or the agent of such owner to properly dispose of litter located on such owner's property which is dangerous to public health, safety or welfare. Such notice shall be by certified mail addressed to such owner at his last known address as indicated on the tax records of the city. 
(b)  Action upon noncompliance. Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner or agent so notified, to properly dispose of litter dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare within seven days after receipt of written notice provided for in subsection (a) of this section, or within ten days after the date of such notice if the same is returned to the city because of the inability of the United States Postal Service to make delivery thereof, provided the same was properly addressed to the last known address of such owner or agent, the officers authorized above are hereby authorized and empowered to order disposal of the litter by the city or private removal agencies designated by the city. 
(c)  Charge included in tax bill. When the city has effected the removal of such litter or has paid for its removal, the actual cost thereof, plus accrued interest at the rate of six percent per annum from the date of the completion of the work shall be paid by the owner within 15 days of the completion of the work. If such is not paid by such owner prior to the next regular tax billing date then such charges shall be charged to the owner of such property on the next regular tax bill forwarded to such owner by the city, and such charges shall be due and payable by the owner at the time of payment of such bill. 
(d)  Recorded statement constitutes lien. Where the full amount due the city is not paid by such owner within 15 days after the disposal of such litter, as provided for in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the city clerk shall cause to be recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court, a sworn statement showing the cost and expense incurred for the work, the date the work was done and the location of the property on which such work was done. The recordation of such sworn statement shall constitute a lien and privilege on the property, and shall remain in full force and effect for the amount due in principal and interest, plus costs of court, if any, for collection, until final payment has been made. Such costs and expenses shall be collected in the manner fixed by law for the collection of taxes and further, shall be subject to a delinquent penalty of ten percent if the same is not paid in full on or before the date the tax bill upon which such charge appears becomes delinquent. Sworn statements recorded in accordance with the provisions of this section shall be prima facie evidence that all legal formalities have been complied with and that the work has been done properly and satisfactorily, and shall be full notice to every person concerned that the amount of the statement, plus interest, constitutes a charge against the property designated or described in the statement and that the same is due and collectible as provided by law. 
(Code 1977, § 14-71) 
Sec. 70-114. - Dumping, depositing, etc., litter on public or private property or waters. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, deposit or throw, or leave or cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing, or leaving of litter on any public or private property in the city or any waters of this city, unless: 
(1)  The property is designated by the state or by one of its agencies or political subdivisions for the disposal of litter and the person is authorized by the proper public authority to use such property; 
(2)  The litter is placed into a litter receptacle or container installed on the property for the purpose of limited use by guests and members of the public; or 
(3)  The person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property or has first obtained consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession or unless the act is done under the personal direction of the owner or tenant, all in a manner consistent with the public welfare. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of household trash or garbage in any container provided by the city, except as provided in section 70-49 of this chapter. 
(c)  Any person who violates subsection (a) of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  By a fine of not more than $500.00 nor more than 90 days in jail. 
(2)  In the sound discretion of the court, the person may be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway, public right-of-way, public park, or with the permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that the person has deposited litter, any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence. 
(d)  The court may publish the names of persons convicted of violating subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. O-92-5, § 7(14-73), 4-6-92; Ord. No. O-97-39, § 1, 5-19-97) 
Sec. 70-115. - Prima facie evidence; rebuttable presumption. 
(a)  Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped, or dumped from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane or other conveyance in violation of section 70-114, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of the conveyance has violated section 70-114. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section, whenever any litter which is dumped, deposited, thrown, or left on public or private property in violation of section 70-114 is discovered to contain any article or articles, including but not limited to letters, bills, publications, or other writings which display the name of a person thereon in such a manner as to indicate that the article belongs or belonged to such person, it shall be a rebuttable presumption that such person has violated section 70-114. 
(Ord. No. O-92-5, § 8(14-74), 4-6-92) 
Secs. 70-116—70-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RESTAURANTS AND SHOPS ON THE DOWNTOWN PLAZA[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-08-015, adopted Apr. 7, 2008, amended art. V in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. V pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-98-69, adopted Sept. 21, 1998. 

Sec. 70-130. - Intent. 
It is the intent of this article to create and maintain a clean, safe, healthy and pleasant environment for the public within the Downtown Plaza, including public places at the rear, front and sides of all buildings within this area, while encouraging and supporting restaurants and other businesses within the Downtown Plaza area. 
(Ord. No. O-08-015, 4-7-08) 
Sec. 70-131. - Applicability. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to restaurants, eating establishments and other businesses (for purposes of this article, hereinafter called "restaurants") generating grease, vegetable waste, food waste, garbage, other waste with an obnoxious smell, or containers having a residue of such material (for purposes of this article, hereinafter collectively called "food waste") located in the Downtown Plaza as defined herein. The provisions of this article shall also apply to all other business establishments (for purposes of this article, hereinafter called "shops") in the Downtown Plaza area from the southern boundary of the Norfolk Southern Railroad right-of-way southward to the northern boundary of the Church Street right-of-way; from the eastern boundary of the Courthouse Square East right-of-way westward to the western boundary of the Campbellton Street right-of-way. Where any provision of this article is in conflict with any other provision of this chapter, the more restrictive provision of the two shall apply. 
(Ord. No. O-08-015, 4-7-08) 
Sec. 70-132. - Responsible party. 
It shall be the duty of every person owning, controlling, managing, operating, policing, renting or occupying any restaurant on the Downtown Plaza to assure compliance of such restaurant with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-08-015, 4-7-08) 
Sec. 70-133. - Accumulation of waste prohibited. 
(a)  Outdoor disposal of food waste prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any restaurant or shop within the Downtown Plaza to deposit or to allow any food waste to accumulate or remain outdoors on the premises of such restaurant or shop, whether or not such food waste or other solid waste is enclosed within any bag, cart or container. 
(b)  Outdoor disposal of non-food waste prohibited for restaurants. It shall be unlawful for any restaurant within the Downtown Plaza to deposit or allow any non-food waste to accumulate or remain outdoors on the premises of such restaurant, whether or not such non-food waste or other solid waste is enclosed within any bag, cart or container, except for non-food recyclables as provided in section 70-134. 
(c)  Outdoor disposal of non-food waste for shops. It shall be unlawful for any shop within the Downtown Plaza to deposit or to allow any non-food waste to accumulate or remain outdoors on the premises of such shop, except in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. O-08-015, 4-7-08) 
Sec. 70-134. - Proper disposal of solid waste. 
(a)  Shops. Shops shall dispose of bagged non-food waste by placing such bags at the rear entrance to the building, not sooner than one and one-half hours prior to any normal scheduled time for collection by the city or its collection franchisee. Exceptionally, non-food recyclables may be disposed of in approved containers, rather than in bags, but the times for collection shall be the same as for other non-food waste. 
(b)  Restaurants. Restaurants shall dispose of food waste and non-food waste by bagging the same and keeping it indoors and accessible for regular backdoor collection by the city or its collection franchisee. Exceptionally, non-food recyclables may be disposed of in approved containers, rather than in bags, but the times for collection shall be the same as for other non-food waste, and recyclable grease may be disposed of through the use of private recycling establishments, but grease shall not be left outdoors for collection nor discharged or leaked onto the ground or pavement incident to recycling. 
(Ord. No. O-08-015, 4-7-08) 
Sec. 70-135. - Fees for disposal. 
The fees for disposal of solid waste by restaurants and shops shall be as determined by the mayor and council from time to time and on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. O-08-015, 4-7-08) 
Sec. 70-136. - Outdoor transporting of food waste prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any restaurant or shop to transport or allow to be transported any food waste, except in accordance with section 70-134. 
(Ord. No. O-08-015, 4-7-08) 
Sec. 70-137. - Outdoor cleaning prohibited.
