Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by this chapter or other ordinances of this city, or by state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and such other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user. The officer shall then conspicuously affix to such vehicle a notice in writing for the driver thereof to answer to the charge against him at the time and place specified in the notice. The form of such written notice shall be as from time to time prescribed by the city or the chief of police. 
(Code 1977, § 24-22) 
Sec. 82-23. - Same—Failure to comply with notices attached to parked vehicle. 
(a)  If a violator of the restrictions on stopping, standing or parking provisions under this chapter or other traffic laws or ordinances does not appear in response to the notice affixed to such vehicle at the place specified on the notice within seven days to pay such fine as may be imposed or to request a hearing in the city recorder's court then the police department is hereby authorized to place wheel locks on such motor vehicle and/or impound such vehicle at owner's expense under the following conditions: 
(1)  Such vehicle has accumulated three or more citations for violations of this chapter or other laws or ordinances relating to the stopping, standing or parking of such vehicle and for which payment has not been made nor a hearing requested. 
(2)  Such citations shall state that failure to pay citations or request a hearing to contest the citation may result in the immobilization or towing of such vehicle that is in violation. 
(3)  Such vehicle was parked upon the public way, street, road or in any public place within the city at the time of impoundment or immobilization. 
(4)  Prior to the immobilization and/or impoundment of such vehicle written notice shall be mailed to the owner of any vehicle which has accumulated three or more outstanding violations for which payment has not been made nor a hearing requested. The notice shall be sent by certified or registered mail to whoever the registered owner of such vehicle was at the time the citations were issued. Such notice shall inform the registered owner of the date, nature and number of outstanding violations, that such vehicle may be immobilized in place and/or impounded, and that such owner will be provided a hearing to contest the validity of the proposed immobilization or impoundment upon written request to the police department within ten days of the date such notice is received. Any owner who requests a hearing to contest the validity of the proposed immobilization or impoundment of such vehicle shall be provided a hearing in the recorder's court. The hearing shall be scheduled as soon as practicable, and enforcement of this section shall be stayed pending the decision of the recorder's court. For the purposes of such hearing, the registered owner of the vehicle shall be presumed to be in possession and control of such vehicle at all times. 
(5)  As soon as the vehicle has been impounded and stored or has been immobilized, the city police officer shall so notify the chief of police or his duly authorized representative, who shall notify, by registered or certified mail, the registered owner of such vehicle at the address listed on the registration within three business days of the impoundment or immobilization. Such notice shall state the location of the vehicle and the requirements for release as set forth in this section. 
(6)  No vehicle shall be released until all citations issued to that vehicle have been paid. When impoundment and immobilization is used an additional charge of $35.00 shall be charged and paid before the vehicle may be released. If the owner of the vehicle wishes to contest the impoundment or immobilization he/she must post a cash bond equal to the outstanding amounts due on all citations issued to such vehicle as well as the $35.00 charged pursuant to this chapter. Such cash bond shall be refunded upon payment of the fine or upon a finding by the recorder's court that the registered owner is not in violation of this section. The bond shall be forfeited unless the person posting it appears in recorder's court in accordance with the summons issued to him at the time of posting such bond. Any person having custody of a motor vehicle impounded pursuant to this chapter or having a means to release any immobilized vehicle shall not release such vehicle until the person requesting the vehicle's release presents evidence of his right to possession of the vehicle and signs a receipt for such vehicle. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this section for any person to tamper with or attempt to tamper with or remove any immobilization device attached to a vehicle, attempt to prevent the removal of any vehicle, or attempt to extract said vehicle from its place of impoundment. The penalty for any such violation shall be not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00. 
(Code 1977, § 24-23) 
Sec. 82-24. - Parking restrictions. 
The city council shall designate all regulations or prohibitions concerning stopping, standing or parking of motor vehicles with respect to streets, roads and highways under its jurisdiction as allowed under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-60-370 et seq., as may be amended. The city council shall cause such regulations and prohibitions to be posted in clear view on the applicable street. Any vehicle found to be in violation of such regulations and prohibitions may be cited, impounded or immobilized. 
(Ord. No. O-91-2, § 2(24-25), 2-18-91) 
Sec. 82-25. - Driving without proper equipment. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle upon the public roads, streets or highways within the city without the proper equipment thereon which is required by any city ordinance or any statute of the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-24, § 1, 6-4-12) 
Sec. 82-26. - Driving too fast for conditions. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle upon the public roads, streets or highways within the city in a manner that is too fast for the conditions of that road, street or highway, as related to traffic, road conditions, weather, darkness or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-24, § 2, 6-4-12) 
Secs. 82-27—82-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Signs, ch. 66. 

Sec. 82-51. - Authority to install generally. 
The chief of police shall cause to be placed and maintained traffic control signs, signals and devices when and as required under this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city to make effective the provisions of this chapter and such ordinances; and may cause to be placed and maintained such additional traffic control devices as they shall deem necessary to regulate traffic under the traffic ordinances of the city or under state law, or to guide or warn traffic. 
(Code 1977, § 24-32) 
Sec. 82-52. - Manual and specifications or traffic control devices. 
All traffic-control signs, signals and devices shall conform as nearly as practicable to specifications in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices developed jointly by the American Association of State Highway Officials, the Institute of Traffic Engineers and the National Conference on Street and Highway Safety. All signals and signs required under this chapter for a particular purpose shall, so far as practicable, be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this chapter shall be official traffic control devices. 
(Code 1977, § 24-33) 
Sec. 82-53. - When required for enforcement. 
No provision of this chapter for which signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if, at the time and place of the alleged violation, an official sign is not so located and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state that signs are required, such section shall be effective even though no signs are erected or in place. 
(Code 1977, § 24-34) 
Sec. 82-54. - Display of unauthorized signs, signals, or markings. 
(a)  No person shall paint, place, maintain or display upon or in view of any street or highway any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device or railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic control device or any railroad sign or signal, and no person shall place or maintain nor shall any public authority permit upon any street or highway any traffic sign or signal bearing on the face thereof any commercial advertising. This section shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private property adjacent to the highway of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signs. 
(b)  Every such prohibited sign, signal, or marking is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and the chief of police is hereby empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without any notice whatsoever. 
(Code 1977, § 24-35) 
Sec. 82-55. - Crosswalks, establish safety zones and mark traffic lanes. 
The chief of police is hereby authorized: 
(1)  To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections and at such other places where in his opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and shall abolish those he deems to be unnecessary. 
(2)  To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(3)  To mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as he may deem advisable, consistent with this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 24-37) 
Sec. 82-56. - School crossings. 
The chief of police is authorized to mark with paint or other devices any crosswalks in the vicinity of any school, where the crossing of such roadway by schoolchildren is deemed dangerous. "School Zone" signs may be placed 100 feet from such crosswalks, on the right-hand side of the street. 
(Code 1977, § 24-38) 
Sec. 82-57. - Restricted turn signs. 
The chief of police is hereby authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right, left or U-turn, and shall place proper signs at such intersections. The making of such turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day and permitted at other hours, in which event the same shall be plainly indicated on the signs or they may be removed when such turns are permitted. 
(Code 1977, § 24-39) 
Sec. 82-58. - Stop signs. 
(a)  Whenever any ordinance of the city designates and describes a boulevard street it shall be the duty of the chief of police to place and maintain a stop sign of each and every street intersecting such boulevard street or intersecting that portion thereof described and designated as such by any ordinance of the city. 
(b)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to determine and designate intersections where particular hazards exist upon other than boulevard streets and to determine whether vehicles shall stop at one or more entrances to any such stop intersection, and shall erect a stop sign at every such place where a stop is required. 
(c)  Every sign erected pursuant to this section shall bear the word "STOP" in letters not less than six inches in height. Every stop sign shall be located as near as practicable at the nearest line of the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or in conformity with the recommendations of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(Code 1977, § 24-40) 
Sec. 82-59. - Signs. 
The chief of police shall place and maintain suitable signs giving notice of all one-way streets, and no regulation as to one-way streets shall be maintained until such signs are so erected and in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Code 1977, § 24-41) 
Sec. 82-60. - Parking control signs. 
(a)  Whenever it is necessary under this chapter or any other ordinance of the city to erect signs or other devices regulating, limiting, or prohibiting parking, standing or stopping of a vehicle in any area, the chief of police shall have the authority to erect such signs or devices as he deems necessary, or that are required under this Code. 
(b)  The chief of police shall further have the authority to erect a no parking sign and to prohibit the parking, standing or stopping of a vehicle in any area where a hazard exists. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to obey any limitation, prohibition or instruction contained in any sign erected under provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 24-42) 
Sec. 82-61. - Taxi stands. 
The chief of police shall have the authority to establish and create or to abolish any taxi stands that he deems to be necessary and proper. Such stands shall be marked by appropriate signs, and it shall be unlawful for any other vehicle, other than a duly licensed taxi, to park therein. 
(Code 1977, § 24-43) 
Secs. 82-62—82-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRUCK ROUTES; SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD LIMITATIONS 

Sec. 82-86. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City means the City of Douglasville. 
Deviating truck means a truck which leaves and departs from a truck route while traveling inside the city. 
Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
Truck means any car, bus or motor vehicle designed or operated for the transportation over the public streets or highways of persons or property, and whose body weight or whose combined body and load weight exceeds five tons. 
Truck route means a way over certain streets as designated in this article, over and along which trucks coming into and going out of the city must operate. 
(Code 1977, § 24-85; Ord. No. O-97-42, § 1, 6-23-97) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-87. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this article shall be guilty of an offense and shall be punished as provided in section 1-3 of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 24-93) 
Sec. 82-88. - Truck route map established. 
A truck route map is hereby established as shown on a map entitled "Truck Route Map of Douglasville, Georgia." The original of such map shall be on file in the office of the city clerk for review and inspection and is by this reference made a part of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 24-86) 
Sec. 82-89. - Application of regulations. 
(a)  All trucks within the city shall be operated only over and along the truck routes established in this article. 
(b)  Exceptions. This article shall not prohibit: 
(1)  Operation on street of destination. The operation of trucks upon any street where necessary to the conduct of business at a destination point, provided streets upon which such traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point. 
(2)  Emergency vehicles. The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street in the city. 
(3)  Public utilities. The operation of trucks owned or operated by the city, county, state or public utilities, any contractor of material man, while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements or street utilities within the city. 
(4)  Detoured trucks. The operation of trucks upon any officially established detour in any case where such truck could lawfully be operated upon the street for which such detour is established. A detour may be established by the city manager, the police chief, or the director of maintenance and sanitation. 
(Code 1977, § 24-87; Ord. No. O-2014-58, § 1, 11-17-14) 
Sec. 82-90. - Truck route established. 
There is hereby established within the city the following truck route. 
(1)  Outside origin; outside destination. All trucks entering the city for destination points outside the city shall operate only over the following designated routes: 
a.  East or west bound truck traffic shall use U.S. Highway 78. 
b.  Northbound traffic shall use State Route 92. 
c.  Southeast bound traffic shall use State Route 92. 
d.  Southwest bound traffic shall use State Route 5. 
e.  As an option, low slung vehicles may use East Strickland Street from Mozley Street West to State Route 92 or West Strickland Street from Rose Avenue East to State Route 92. 
f.  As an option to use of portions of State Route 92 east of Hospital Drive, northbound vehicles and southeast bound vehicles may use Hospital Drive from its intersection with State Route 92 southwest to its intersection with Campbellton Street, and Campbellton Street from its intersection with Hospital Drive south to its intersection with Interstate Highway 20. 
(Code 1977, § 24-88; Ord. No. O-98-77, § 1, 10-19-98) 
Sec. 82-91. - Truck traffic in the city. 
(a)  One inside destination point. All trucks entering the city for a destination point in the city shall proceed only over an established truck route and shall deviate only at the intersection nearest to the destination point. Upon leaving the destination point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route. 
(b)  Multiple inside destination points. All trucks entering the city for multiple destination points shall proceed only over established truck routes and shall deviate only at the intersection nearest to the first destination point. Upon leaving the first destination point, a deviating truck shall proceed to other destination points by the shortest direction. Upon leaving the last destination point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route. 
(c)  Inside origin trips. 
(1)  Outside destination point. All trucks on a trip originating in the city shall proceed by the shortest direction to a truck route as established in this article. 
(2)  Inside destination points. All trucks on a trip originating in the city and traveling in the city for destination points in the city shall proceed to a truck route as established in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 24-89) 
Sec. 82-92. - Maximum width, height and length limitations. 
No vehicle operated upon any public street within the city exclusive of those public streets which are also a part of the state or federal highway system, except vehicles designed to carry passengers shall exceed a total outside width, including load thereon, of 96 inches, not including mirrors and accessories attached thereto. No vehicle unloaded or with a load shall exceed a height of 13 feet, six inches. No vehicle or combination of vehicles shall exceed a total length of 55 feet. 
(Code 1977, § 24-90) 
Sec. 82-93. - Maximum weight of vehicles using city streets. 
No vehicle operating upon any public street within the city limits of Douglasville, exclusive of those streets which are a part of the state or federal highway system, shall exceed five tons and be equipped with three or more axles, except vehicles that are required to deviate from the established truck route as covered in section 82-91. 
(Code 1977, § 24-91) 
Sec. 82-94. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The chief of police of the city shall cause all truck routes to be clearly sign-posted to give notice that this article is in effect. 
(b)  The chief of police shall have the authority to require any person driving or in control of any commercial vehicle not proceeding over a truck route and not in the process of making or picking up a delivery to proceed to any public or private scale available for the purpose of weighing and determining whether this article has been complied with. 
(Code 1977, § 24-92) 
Secs. 82-95—82-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 82-121. - Authority. 
The chief of police shall have the authority to impound or remove from the streets any vehicle found in violation of the provisions of this chapter. The chief of police shall have the authority to impound or remove from the streets any vehicle involved in any collision or accident whenever the owner thereof cannot be found after reasonable effort or whenever the owner thereof refuses to move the same from the streets. 
(Code 1977, § 24-55) 
Sec. 82-122. - Removal of vehicle; storage. 
Whenever the chief of police has impounded a vehicle under the terms and provisions of this article he shall remove the vehicle to any place of storage designated by the mayor and council and there store the vehicle until the same is called for by the owner thereof or disposed of as provided in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 24-56) 
Sec. 82-123. - Charges. 
The owner of any vehicle impounded under the provisions of this article shall be liable for all costs incurred as a result of such impoundment as the same shall be determined by the mayor and council from time to time. 
(Code 1977, § 24-57) 
Sec. 82-124. - Refusal of owner to claim vehicle or pay towing fees. 
Whenever the owner of any vehicle shall fail or refuse to claim any vehicle impounded under the terms and conditions contained in this article or whenever the owner of any vehicle shall fail or refuse to pay the towing fees in connection with such impounding, the city is hereby authorized to advertise such vehicle for sale at public sale, such advertising to appear once a week for four weeks in the newspaper in which the sheriff's advertisements appear, and to then sell the same to the highest bidder for cash at such public sale. The proceeds of such sale shall be applied first to the payment of the charges due the city as a result of such impounding and the expenses of the sale, and the balance, if any, delivered to the owner of the vehicle. If the owner of the vehicle cannot be found or discovered, the finance director shall hold the proceeds of the sale for a period of six months, and, at the end of that period, if the owner has not appeared to claim the balance, pay the balance over to the city. 
(Code 1977, § 24-58; Ord. No. O-2013-53, § 16, 12-16-13) 
Secs. 82-125—82-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ABANDONED OR DISMANTLED MOTOR VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 38. 

Sec. 82-151. - Short title. 
This article shall be known, and may be cited, as the Abandoned, Wrecked, Dismantled or Inoperative Motor Vehicle Ordinance. 
(Code 1977, § 14-31) 
Sec. 82-152. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. 
City means the City of Douglasville, Georgia. 
Director of public safety means the director of public safety of the City of Douglasville, Georgia. 
Junked motor vehicle means any motor vehicle which: (a) does not have lawfully affixed thereto an unexpired license plate or plates and proper proof of paid taxes, or (b) the condition of which is wrecked, dismantled, partially dismantled, inoperative, abandoned or discarded. 
Motor vehicle means any vehicle which is self-propelled and designed to travel along the ground and shall include, but not be limited to, automobiles, buses, motorbikes, motorcycles, motorscooters, trucks, tractors, go-carts, golf carts, campers and trailers. 
Private property means any real property within the city which is privately owned and which is not public property. 
Public property means any street or highway, which shall include the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained for the purposes of vehicular travel, and also means any other publicly owned property or facility. 
Vehicle immobilization device, device, or boot means any mechanical device that is designed or adopted to be attached to a wheel, tire, or other part of a parked motor vehicle so as to prohibit the motor vehicle's usual manner of movement or operation. 
(Code 1977, § 14-32; Ord. No. O-05-46, § 1, 8-1-05; Ord. No. O-2015-9, § 1, 2-16-15) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-153. - Penalties. 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-3. 
(Code 1977, § 14-40) 
Sec. 82-154. - Separate offenses. 
Failure to comply with the provisions of this article after such violator shall have been notified and cited as provided in this article, shall each day constitute a separate and distinct offense, and continuing violations shall be cited and prosecuted from time to time as may be required under the circumstances, until full compliance with all provisions of this article is had. 
(Code 1977, § 14-41) 
Sec. 82-155. - Storing, parking or leaving dismantled or other such motor vehicles prohibited, declared nuisance; exceptions. 
No person shall park, store or leave, or permit the parking, storing or leaving of, any motor vehicle of any kind which is in an abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperative, rusted, junked or partially dismantled condition, whether attended or not, upon any public or private property within the city for a period of time in excess of 72 hours. The presence of an abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperative, rusted, junked or partially dismantled vehicle or parts thereof, on private or public property is hereby declared a public nuisance which may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this article. This section shall apply to any vehicle held inside an open carport and to any vehicle notwithstanding its being maintained beneath a cover other than an enclosed building. This section shall not apply to any vehicle enclosed within a building on private property or to any vehicle held in connection with a business enterprise properly operated in the appropriate business zone and lawfully licensed by the city as an automobile service station, an automotive repair shop, an automobile storage lot, or a junkyard. 
(Code 1977, § 14-33; Ord. No. O-00-44, § 1, 4-3-00) 
Sec. 82-156. - Notice to remove. 
Whenever it comes to the attention of the director of public safety that any nuisance, as defined in section 82-155 exists in the city, a notice in writing shall be served upon the occupant of the land where the nuisance exists, or in case there is no such occupant, then upon the owner of the property or his agent, notifying them of the existence of the nuisance and requesting its removal in the time specified in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 14-34) 
Sec. 82-157. - Responsibility for removal. 
Upon proper notice and opportunity to be heard, the owner of the abandoned, wrecked, dismantled or inoperative vehicle and the owner or occupant of the private property on which the same is located, either or all of them, shall be responsible for its removal. Upon removal and disposition by the city, the owner or occupant of the private property where same is located shall be liable for the expenses incurred. 
(Code 1977, § 14-35) 
Sec. 82-158. - Notice of removal. 
The director of public safety of the city, or his designated subordinate, shall give notice of removal to the owner or occupant of the private property where the vehicle is located, at least ten days before the time of compliance. It shall constitute sufficient notice when a copy of same is either: (a) posted in a conspicuous place upon the private property on which the vehicle is located and duplicate copies are sent by registered mail to the owner or occupant of the private property at his last known address, or (b) delivered personally to the owner or occupant of the private property. 
(Code 1977, § 14-36; Ord. No. O-00-44, § 2, 4-3-00) 
Sec. 82-159. - Content of notice. 
The notice shall contain the request for removal within the time specified in this article, and the notice shall advise that upon failure to comply with the notice to remove, the occupant and/or owner of the premises shall be subject to citation in the recorder's court of the city, for the violation of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 14-37) 
Sec. 82-160. - Failure to remove. 
(a)  If the violation described in the notice has not been remedied within the ten day period specified in the notice of compliance, the city may, in addition to bringing criminal charges against the occupant and/or owner of the property in recorder's court, bring an action for injunctive relief against such offenders in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(b)  Police officers of the city may enter upon private property for the purposes specified in this article, to examine vehicles or parts thereof, obtain information as to the ownership of vehicles and property, and such other purposes as may be reasonably necessary. The recorder's court of the city shall have the authority to issue all orders and warrants necessary to enforce this article. 
(Code 1977, § 14-38) 
Sec. 82-161. - [Vehicle immobilization by boot or similar device.] 
Immobilization of the vehicle of another by use of a boot or other similar device is prohibited, except on private property having a current business license for wrecker service, junk yard or automobile repair. 
( Ord. No. O-2015-9, § 1 , 2-16-15) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2015-9, § 2 , adopted Feb. 16, 2015, added a new § 82-161 to read as set out herein and renumbered the former § 82-161 as a new § 82-162. The former § 82-161 pertained to application of state law. 
Sec. 82-162. - Application of state law. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to limit or restrict such right to remove and dispose of abandoned vehicles from public property as is presently, or in the future may be, granted to the city pursuant to the laws of the state. 
(Code 1977, § 14-39; Ord. No. O-2015-9, § 2 , 2-16-15) 
Note— See note at § 82-161. 
Secs. 82-163—82-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BICYCLES 

Sec. 82-181. - Rules of road apply to bicycles. 
All rules of the road that apply to motor vehicles in the city shall also apply to the operation and riding of bicycles unless otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 24-71) 
Sec. 82-182. - Manner of riding. 
Riders of bicycles shall not ride with both hands off the handlebars or coast, when about to meet or pass any other person or vehicle, and they shall at all times have full control of their mounts. 
(Code 1977, § 24-72) 
Sec. 82-183. - Riding on sidewalks. 
No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within any business district in the city, and no person more than 14 years of age shall ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk in any district. Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. 
(Code 1977, § 24-76) 
Sec. 82-184. - Acrobatic, fancy riding, racing prohibited. 
No rider of any bicycle shall remove both hands from the handlebars, or both feet from the pedal, or practice any acrobatic or fancy riding on any sidewalk or any street; nor shall any person operating a bicycle upon a street or sidewalk participate in any race of speed or endurance in a contest with any other bicycle or vehicle. 
(Code 1977, § 24-77) 
Sec. 82-185. - Riding more than two abreast prohibited. 
No more than two bicycles or other similar vehicle shall be ridden abreast on any street or sidewalk in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 24-78) 
Sec. 82-186. - Lights. 
Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a light on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of 300 feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear of a type approved by the state department of public safety which shall be visible from a distance of 300 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of headlights on a motor vehicle. A light emitting a red light visible from a distance of 300 feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. 
(Code 1977, § 24-79) 
Secs. 82-187—82-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - RAILROADS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-211. - Speed. 
(a)  Any agent, employee, or servant of any railroad company operating a railroad car, engine, locomotive, or train in the city shall operate the same at a careful and prudent rate of speed not greater than is reasonable and proper and safe, having due regard to the traffic on the street intersecting such railroad, and of any other condition then existing, and such agent, employee, or servant shall be at all times able to bring such railroad car, engine, locomotive or train to a complete stop short of any motor vehicle, person, or other object or obstruction that may be upon any crossing. 
(b)  No agent, employee, or servant of any railroad company operating a railroad car, engine, locomotive, or train in the city shall operate the same at any place in the city designated as a business district at a speed greater than 30 miles per hour. 
(c)  No agent, employee, or servant of any railroad company operating a railroad car, engine, locomotive, or train in the city shall back the same at any place in the city at a speed greater than ten miles per hour. 
(d)  No agent, employee, or servant of any railroad company operating a railroad car, engine, locomotive, or train in the city shall operate the same at any place in the city designated as a residential district at a speed greater than 35 miles per hour. 
(Code 1977, § 21-1) 
Sec. 82-212. - Blocking street crossings. 
No street crossing shall be blocked or obstructed by any railroad train, car or engine that is not in motion for longer at any one time than five minutes, and then only to allow the coupling and uncoupling of cars; provided, that this section shall not apply in cases of accident and absolute necessity. 
(Code 1977, § 21-2) 
Sec. 82-213. - Flying switch. 
It shall be unlawful for any car, or string of cars, when put in motion by an engine, to be detached from the engine or train until the same shall have been fully stopped. 
(Code 1977, § 21-3) 
Sec. 82-214. - Jumping on or off trains while in motion. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, except a railroad employee, to jump on or off an engine or car while it is in motion. 
(Code 1977, § 21-4) 
Sec. 82-215. - Riding on trains within city. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, not a member of the train crew or otherwise connected with the running of such train, to ride upon any railroad engine, passenger coach, freight or other car within the city when the same is not actually engaged in the transportation of passengers; provided, that this section shall not apply to persons authorized to ride thereon by the proper officials of the railroad company controlling the same. 
(Code 1977, § 21-5) 
Sec. 82-216. - Maintenance of right-of-way. 
Any railroad company operating a line of track within the city shall keep the right-of-way free and clear of any garbage, refuse, junk, or other matter that might be a danger to the health, welfare, morals, and safety of the citizens of the city. Any railroad company operating a line of track within the city shall keep the grass and the weeds thereon cut and properly trimmed so as not to constitute a fire hazard due to tall and uncut and unkept grass and weeds. 
(Code 1977, § 21-6) 
Sec. 82-217. - Standing of cars regulated. 
It shall be unlawful for any railroad company to permit any freight or other railroad car to be stopped or parked within 50 feet of any railroad crossing, and such car shall never be parked or stopped so as to block the vision of any approaching train by any person desiring the use of the crossing. 
(Code 1977, § 21-7) 
Sec. 82-218. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this division shall be guilty of an offense and may be punished as provided in section 1-3 of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 24-102) 
Secs. 82-219—82-235. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VEHICULAR TRAFFIC AT CERTAIN CROSSINGS 

Sec. 82-236. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City means the City of Douglasville, Georgia. 
Person means any business, firm, partnership, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
Truck means any vehicle equipped with three or more axles. "Truck" shall also include any vehicle combined with or towing a trailer, flatbed or other vehicle. 
(Code 1977, § 24-100) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-237. - Certain railroad crossings prohibited to truck traffic. 
The railroad crossings located within the City of Douglasville, Georgia, at the intersection of Campbellton Street, U.S. Highway 78 and Georgia State Highway 92, and at the intersection of U.S. Highway 78, Price Street, and Strickland Street are hereby prohibited to truck traffic. 
(Code 1977, § 24-101) 
Chapter 86 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; plumbing code, § 22-166 et seq.; energy code for buildings, § 22-286 et seq.; housing code, § 22-311 et seq.; community development, ch. 34; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; tampering with fire hydrant, § 42-4; floods, ch. 46; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 54; entry on city reservoir property, § 58-8; discharge of phosphates, § 58-13; solid waste, ch. 70; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; utilities in city streets or rights-of-way, § 74-166 et seq.; subdivision regulations, app. B; required improvements in subdivisions, app. B, § 110 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Consumer means any person, establishment, unit or space served on or through any water meter other than the customer in whose name the meter is listed or from whom payment may be required. 
Customer means the owner of the property served by a water connection, or the tenant, lessee, renter, establishment or occupant of such property, or the person in or against whose name the water connection for such property is listed on the books and records of the city, and who is responsible to the city for payment of bills incurred for water furnished to such property and for use by such property of the public sewer system of the city, either or both. 
Minimum monthly bill means the fixed minimum monthly payment required for a water meter or connection calculated under the provisions of this chapter. Single customers or meter services serving more than one family or dwelling unit per meter shall be charged a minimum monthly bill equal to the minimum monthly billing rate multiplied by the number of family or dwelling units served by such meter. Charges for all amounts exceeding the minimum monthly usage amount per unit shall be charged as all other customers or consumers. This shall apply to all water, sewer and garbage services provided by the city. 
User means a water customer whose property also discharges sewage, wastes or water into the public sanitary sewer system of the city in any quantity. 
Utility means water, sewer and/or any other utility service furnished by the city to consumers thereof. 
(Code 1977, § 25-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 86-2. - Scope of provisions. 
All pertinent provisions of this chapter are hereby made a part of the terms and conditions whereby the city shall furnish any utility service to any person, or whereby the city shall make any utility connections or perform any work of any kind in connection with the furnishing of any utility service pursuant to the rules and regulations of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1977, § 25-2) 
Sec. 86-3. - Service to comply with technical provisions. 
Any utility service furnished under the provisions of this chapter shall be in accordance with and in compliance with all applicable technical provisions of this Code, state law and city ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(Code 1977, § 25-3) 
Sec. 86-4. - Rules, regulations. 
The mayor and council shall have the authority to establish by rule or regulation such standards and specifications as may be deemed necessary for the installation, construction and maintenance of any utility service system owned and operated by the city within or without the city and under the management of the city. Such rules, regulations, standards and specifications shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. Violation of such rules, regulations, standards and specifications shall be deemed an offense punishable as provided in section 1-3 of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 25-4) 
Sec. 86-5. - Area of service. 
The area of service for all utilities owned and/or operated by the city shall be the area that is contained within the corporate limits. To be served by a city utility the building, establishment, unit, space or other improvement must be wholly, and in its entirety, located within the corporate limits of the city; however, the mayor and council upon application, may, in its discretion, permit utility service to be extended to a building, establishment, unit, space or other improvement which, by a reason of its location, cannot be served under this section. 
(Code 1977, § 25-5) 
Sec. 86-6. - Compliance with building code and other codes. 
No building, establishment, unit, space or other improvement shall be served by a utility owned and/or operated by the city unless such building, establishment, unit, space or other improvement was constructed under a building permit, plumbing permit or other required permit issued by the city and was inspected during the construction thereof as required by the codes, rules, and regulations of the city which are applicable. If the building, establishment, unit, space or other improvement was built or constructed before April, 1972, then such building, establishment, unit, space or other improvement may be served by a utility owned and/or operated by the city after inspection by the building official and certification that such building, establishment, unit, space or other improvement complies with all applicable codes, rules and regulations of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 25-5.1) 
Sec. 86-7. - Right of entry. 
Any authorized inspector of the city shall have free access at any time to all premises supplied with any utility service by the city for the purpose of examination in order to protect the utility service from abusive use. 
(Code 1977, § 25-6) 
Sec. 86-8. - Termination of service authorized. 
The city shall have the right to disconnect or refuse to connect or reconnect any utility service for the following reasons pertaining to that utility service, such as water and sewer: 
(1)  Failure to meet the applicable provisions of law. 
(2)  Violation of the rules and regulations pertaining to utility service. 
(3)  Nonpayment of bills. 
(4)  Willful or negligent waste of service due to improper or imperfect pipes, fixtures, appliances or otherwise. 
(5)  Molesting any meter, seal or other equipment controlling or regulating the supply of utility service. 
(6)  Theft or diversion and/or use of service without payment therefor. 
(7)  Vacancy of premises. 
(Code 1977, § 25-7) 
Sec. 86-9. - Liability of city for damage. 
The city shall not be liable for any damage to any customer of any utility service furnished by the city due to backflow of the sewerage system, failure of supply, interruption of service or any other cause outside the direct control of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 25-8) 
Sec. 86-10. - Utility service—Application required. 
Any person desiring any utility service furnished by the city shall make application for the same to the water department. 
(Code 1977, § 25-9) 
Sec. 86-11. - Same—Use assumed. 
All premises connected to any utility service of the city shall be assumed to be using such utility service and the owner or occupant shall be charged therefor so long as such premises remain connected with the utility service. 
(Code 1977, § 25-10) 
Sec. 86-12. - Damage, trespass of equipment. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, not having authority to do so, to open any water hydrant or tamper with any utility service furnished by the city to consumers, or to in any other way molest, damage or trespass upon any equipment or premises belonging to the city connected with any utility service. 
(Code 1977, § 25-12) 
Sec. 86-13. - Restricting use. 
The city hereby reserves the right to at any time restrict or prevent the use of any utility service furnished by the city during periods of emergency or circumstances demanding such restriction or prevention of use. 
(Code 1977, § 25-14) 
Sec. 86-14. - Sale of service by customer. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to resell any utility service obtained from the city to others except by special arrangement with the mayor and council. 
(Code 1977, § 25-15) 
Sec. 86-15. - Unlawful connections. 
Any person who shall make any connection in any manner to any utility system, whether owned by the city or not, without the prior knowledge and consent of the owner of such utility system shall be deemed guilty of an offense punishable as provided in section 1-3 of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 25-18) 
Secs. 86-16—86-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 86-46. - Penalty for nonpayment; discontinuance of service; charge for resumption of service. 
(a)  If any consumer, customer or user of any water, sewer, garbage or similar utility service provided by the City of Douglasville fails to make payment for such service within 15 days from the date a bill is rendered for such service, there shall be added to the total charges on the bill or statement for said services, a penalty of ten percent of the gross amount of the entire statement. If the entire amount together with the penalty is not paid by such consumer, customer or user on or before five days from the date such penalty is assessed, then the service or services received by such consumer, customer or user shall be discontinued and stopped immediately; provided that payments owed for one service such as garbage collection shall not be grounds for discontinuance of another service such as water and sewer. 
(b)  After service has been discontinued for nonpayment, the consumer, customer or user will be required to pay all outstanding charges for the service or services plus all penalties, and a fee of $5.00 before service will be resumed. In cases where the discontinuance of service results in the removal of any metering devices or receptacles, then the city, in its discretion, may require as a condition to resumption of service the payment of fees and charges for the reinstallation of metering devices and receptacles. 
(Code 1977, § 25-38) 
Cross reference— Fees for refuse collection, § 70-41. 
Secs. 86-47—86-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to construct, build, maintain, sewers, sewage treatment, § 1.03(h). 
Cross reference— Plumbing code, § 22-166 et seq.; discharge of phosphates, § 58-13. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-71. - Unlawful discharge of sewage. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or allow to be discharged any sewage into or upon any highway, stream, open drain or watercourse, or onto any drain, cesspool, or private sewer. 
(Code 1977, § 25-57) 
Sec. 86-72. - Discharge from kitchens, etc., to be through sink to sanitary sewer. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any sewerage or waste from kitchens, washings of clothing or of meats, fish or other foods, otherwise than through a sink, which shall be properly connected with the sanitary sewerage system of the city by proper piping. 
(Code 1977, § 25-58) 
Sec. 86-73. - Discharge from water closets or toilets and bathrooms. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any sewerage or waste from water closets or toilets and bathrooms otherwise than through a system of proper piping which shall be connected with the sanitary sewerage system of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 25-59) 
Sec. 86-74. - Drainage of surface water or stormwater into sewerage system prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drain or allow to be drained any surface water or stormwater into the sewerage system of the city, unless the sewer drained into shall be a regular storm sewer. 
(Code 1977, § 25-60) 
Sec. 86-75. - Washwater, garbage, etc., prohibited in surface closet. 
No washwater, garbage, kitchen slops or other liquid wastes shall be emptied into a surface closet. 
(Code 1977, § 25-61) 
Sec. 86-76. - Oxidation pond, ditch prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, operate or maintain a sewage treatment facility commonly known as an oxidation pond or oxidation ditch within the corporate limits of the city. All persons who contribute or assist in any manner to the construction, operation or maintenance of such a prohibited facility shall be deemed to have violated this section. 
(Code 1977, § 25-62) 
Secs. 86-77—86-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 86-91. - Repair of streets to be made by owner. 
The owner of any property or building to be connected with the sewerage system shall repair any and all breaks in the street paving or ballast made necessary by his connection with the sewerage system. The expense of this repair shall be borne by the owner of the property or building to be connected, and such repair must be approved by the superintendent of streets or by the city engineer. 
(Code 1977, § 25-75) 
Sec. 86-92. - Repair of settlement over drains. 
Any settlement over a drain connected with the sewerage system on any street or public way occurring within 60 days after the laying of a drain shall be repaired at the expense of the owner of the property or building connected and by the owner of the property or building connected. 
(Code 1977, § 25-76) 
Sec. 86-93. - Method of opening trenches in streets. 
In opening trenches in any street or public way, the paving or ballast must be removed with care, the sides of the trench must be sheeted or braced when directed and in the manner directed by the city engineer or superintendent of streets. The earth thrown from the trench must be placed so as not to obstruct the gutter and so as to cause the least obstruction to public travel. Gas and water pipes must be protected from injury, the trench enclosed and lighted at night and every precaution taken to prevent injury to persons or property during the progress of the work. 
(Code 1977, § 25-77) 
Chapter 90 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE III. - WRECKER SERVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, adopted Oct. 2, 2017, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. III, §§ 90-136—90-156, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-02-31, § 1, adopted Aug. 5, 2002; Ord. No. O-03-37, §§ 1, 2, 5, adopted Nov. 3, 2003; Ord. No. O-2012-11, § 1, adopted March 5, 2012; Ord. No. O-2016-51, § 1, adopted Nov. 7, 2016; and Ord. No. O-2016-59, § 1, adopted Dec. 19, 2016. 

Sec. 90-136. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Approved heavy wrecker service means an approved wrecker service whose equipment list includes a wrecker rated to tow tractor trailers. 
Approved wrecker service means any wrecker service which submits a successful application under this article and which otherwise complies with the provisions hereof to qualify for the privilege of engagement by the police department for the removal or storage of vehicles. 
Basic tow job includes furnishings of wrecker and up to 30 minutes of work necessary to properly hook up an undamaged vehicle and tow it to a storage area. 
Damaged vehicle means any vehicle suffering such mechanical or structural damage to the extent that it cannot properly or safely be operated. 
Passenger vehicle means any vehicle weighing up to 10,000 pounds of gross vehicle weight. 
Police department means the police department, its officers, agents or employees. 
Property owner means the owner of property, or his authorized representative, upon which a vehicle to be removed is located. 
Response time means that the time the wrecker service arrives at the scene of the traffic infringement after a call is received from the police department to respond. This time should not exceed 30 minutes. 
Undamaged vehicle means any vehicle which has no or only minor structural or mechanical damage and is capable of being safely and properly operated. 
Vehicle owner means the owner of a vehicle or his authorized representative. 
Wrecker means an automotive vehicle with hoisting apparatus and equipment for towing wrecked, disabled or abandoned automobiles or other vehicles. The term "wrecker" also includes any vehicle otherwise equipped and used for the purpose of towing wrecked, disabled or abandoned automobiles or other vehicles. 
Wrecker service means any corporation, partnership or individual person, either as principal, agent or employee in the business of removing, towing and/or storing vehicles abandoned in the roadway or on other public lands, or wrecked or disabled vehicles by the use of a wrecker and properly licensed by the state. For corporations and partnerships, the term shall include any individual owning a 20 percent or greater interest in the entity. Wrecker service does not include towing of trespassing vehicles or personal property from private land. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-137. - Private towing of trespassing vehicles excluded. 
Removal of vehicles and trespassing private property from privately owned real property shall be regulated by the Georgia Department of Motor Vehicle Safety, as provided in O.C.G.A. § 44-1-13. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-138. - Application for approved wrecker permit, heavy wrecker permit. 
Each wrecker service desiring to be added to the city approved wrecker service list or the approved heavy wrecker list to respond to calls for wrecker services from the city shall make application to the police chief annually for an approved wrecker permit. The police chief shall accept applications for approved wrecker permits annually from August 1 through October 31 for permits to be valid for the subsequent calendar year. The application shall be submitted on a form provided by the police department and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee of $50.00. No application shall be processed unless all required documents have been submitted. Such application shall include but not be limited to the following information: 
(1)  Listing of name and address of the owner of the wrecker service. If held by a corporation, the names and address of its officers and any stockholders holding 20 percent or more of the corporate stock; if held by a partnership listing names of all partners. 
(2)  Complete list of towing equipment, including the VIN number for motor vehicles, noting any wreckers which are rated to tow tractor trailers. 
(3)  List of all personnel employed by wrecker service, including job description and training received. 
(4)  Certificate of insurance showing compliance with requirements contained in this article. 
(5)  A copy of the fee schedule to be in effect for 12 months following application approval. 
(6)  A copy of a current valid business license from the city and a permit from the Georgia Department of Motor Vehicle Safety, as well as evidence of legally operating a wrecker service in Douglas County for 12 months preceding application. 
(7)  Complete list of all addresses of impound/vehicle storage sites to be utilized by the wrecker service. 
(8)  A complete list of the names of all individuals and employees who will drive a wrecker for the applicant, which shall include the name of the applicant if the applicant is an individual and will be a driver. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-139. - Processing of application. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a timely and complete application for an approved wrecker permit or an approved heavy wrecker permit, the police department shall examine the application for completeness, perform any necessary investigation, and inspect the equipment, storage lot(s) and business location for the applicant. Thereafter the police chief shall approve or deny the application. 
(b)  Denial. The police chief shall have due cause to deny any application for an approved wrecker permit or approved heavy wrecker permit for the following reasons: 
(1)  The application has remained incomplete for 30 days due to the failure of applicant to provide any paper or document required in the application or requested additional information. 
(2)  The applicant has provided false information in the application. 
(3)  The applicant, during the preceding 12 months from the application date, had a wrecker service business license held by such owner revoked for cause by the state or by any political subdivision thereof, or the business or owner of the business has been convicted by any court of competent jurisdiction of engaging in unfair business practices with respect to the operation of any wrecker service. 
(4)  The applicant does not employ at least two proposed drivers who can obtain approved wrecker employee identification cards, or the applicant does not have the equipment required by this article to provide service. 
(5)  The applicant does not have an impound facility as required in this article. 
(6)  The applicant, if the applicant is an individual, has a conviction of any violent felony, or any serious driving offense as defined in O.C.G.A. Title 40, Chapter 6, Article 15, or currently has a suspended or revoked driver's license. 
If the police chief denies any application for an approved wrecker permit or approved heavy wrecker permit, he shall do so in writing and shall notify the applicant of his decision and reasons for his decision. 
(c)  Approval. If the police chief does not deny any timely and complete application for one or more reasons stated in paragraph (a) of this section, then he shall approve the application and issue the requested approved wrecker permit or approved heavy wrecker permit to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-140. - Approved wrecker services, approved heavy wrecker services, rotating on-call list. 
At the conclusion of the annual application and permitting process, the police department shall compile an annual list of approved wrecker services and approved heavy wrecker services. Every approved heavy wrecker service shall be shown on both lists. The police department shall make use of the wrecker services on each list on a rotating on-call basis for accidents where the owner of any vehicle does not have a preference for a wrecker service to be utilized. Each permit holder on the approved wrecker service list shall be utilized as the on-call service for one continuous week, on an equal rotating basis. Each permit holder on the approved heavy wrecker service list shall be utilized as the on-call service for towing tractor trailers for two continuous weeks, on an equal rotating basis, for towing of tractor trailers whenever the on-call approved wrecker service is not also an approved heavy wrecker service. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-141. - Approved wrecker employee identification. 
(a)  No person shall drive a wrecker for an approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service without first obtaining an approved wrecker employee identification card from the police department. 
(b)  All such persons shall apply to the police department for an approved wrecker employee identification card, which card shall expire at the end of the calendar year of issuance and shall be renewable on or before that time. An approved wrecker employee identification card shall be valid for such work at any location within the city having a valid approved wrecker permit or approved heavy wrecker permit. 
(c)  Such persons shall make themselves available for photographing, fingerprinting and such other investigating as may be required by the police department. 
(d)  Each driver applicant shall submit a copy of his valid state driver's license, with the appropriate classification to operate wrecker service equipment, shall consent to a criminal background check. For any application made other than in conjunction with an application for an approved wrecker permit or approved heavy wrecker permit, the applicant shall pay a fee of $25.00 for the criminal background records check and identification card. 
(e)  The police department shall investigate the employee application and report any detrimental information to the chief of police. The chief of police may refuse to issue an approved wrecker employee identification card to any proposed employee who has been convicted of a violent felony. 
(f)  Any identification card holder shall, within 48 hours, report to the police department the suspension or revocation such employee's driver's license. 
(g)  No approved wrecker permit holder or approved heavy wrecker permit holder shall allow or require any person to drive a wrecker without an approved wrecker employee identification card; permit holders shall require all such drivers to wear or otherwise properly display their identification cards at all times during working hours. 
(h)  The chief of police may revoke an identification card should the driver violate any provisions of this article, furnish false or misleading information in the employee's application or commit conduct adversely affecting the public health, safety or welfare. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful for a driver whose identification card has been revoked, when demand for surrender of a card has been made, to refuse to so surrender, or to alter, conceal, deface or destroy such card. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-142. - Unapproved wrecker services to comply with article. 
It shall be unlawful for any wrecker service, whether an approved wrecker service, or not, to respond to police department calls for wrecker assistance on the streets of the city without complying with the provisions of this article. In unusual or emergency situations if the on call wrecker service determines that it is in need of additional assistance from another wrecker service, the on-call wrecker service may seek assistance from any wrecker service that has been approved by the city under the provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-143. - Identification of all wreckers. 
All wreckers which operate upon any of the streets of the city shall be clearly identified as such, with the name and domicile of the wrecker service operating the wrecker. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-144. - Limitations upon proceeding to accident scene. 
No wrecker shall go to any accident scene unless: 
(1)  Called by the police department; 
(2)  Called by the vehicle owner; 
(3)  There exists an extreme emergency immediately endangering life or property; or 
(4)  Called by the property owner where vehicle located. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-145. - Prohibition against monitor running. 
No wrecker service shall proceed to an accident scene by reason of any information received by monitoring police radio calls. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-146. - Use of due care. 
(a)  Wrecker services shall determine the method and manner of removing vehicles; provided, however, that they shall exercise due care in removal operations and shall follow the direction of the traffic officer directing the removal so as not to impede traffic or endanger the general public and property. 
(b)  The driver of each wrecker truck towing away any vehicle from the scene of a wreck shall also take away all parts belonging to the vehicle which is being towed away, or, if they consist of small parts or broken glass, driver shall clear the streets of said small parts and glass, unless the driver is ordered not to do so by the investigating police officer due to circumstances at the scene of the accident. No additional fee may be charged for this clean up. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-147. - Information supplied to police department; notification to owner. 
(a)  Whenever any wrecked or abandoned vehicle is removed without the request, direction or participation of the police department, the wrecker service performing the removal shall, if the owner is unknown, within 72 hours of such removal, furnish to the police department the following information with respect to such vehicle: Tag number and description, including year, model, make, color, and vehicle identification number. 
(b)  The wrecker service shall notify the vehicle owner of the time and place of removal and of the present whereabouts of the vehicle, as required by O.C.G.A. section 40-11-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-148. - Vehicle inventory; procedures. 
Whenever any vehicle is removed by a wrecker service at the direction of a police officer, the police officer shall make a thorough inventory of all equipment, accessories, personal articles and other items either attached to or located within the vehicle. Such inventory shall be completed on a form supplied by the police department and signed by the officer in charge of the removal. Upon acceptance of the vehicle and prior to its removal, the agent or employee of the wrecker service performing the removal shall sign the inventory form. The officer shall retain the original and the wrecker service shall retain a copy. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-149. - Wrecker services to hold vehicles upon direction of police. 
When specifically directed to do so by the police department, the wrecker service shall hold vehicles for evidence, confiscation or any other purposes permitted by law. Upon the written and signed authorization of the police department on a form prescribed by the police department, the wrecker services shall release any vehicle so held to the owner, his authorized representative or other person entitled by law to possession of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-150. - Police department calls to wrecker services; owner's choices of wrecker service. 
(a)  A vehicle owner in ordinary, non-emergency situations, may engage a private wrecker service of his choice to remove his vehicle. The responding officer shall advise the vehicle owner of his option to call the wrecker service of the owner's choice that is capable of responding in a reasonable amount of time. 
(b)  If the owner states no preference, the police officer shall request Douglas County 911 to call whichever approved wrecker service is on duty for that particular week in the rotation. Each approved wrecker service shall be on call for one week beginning at 7:00 a.m. Monday morning until the following Monday morning. 
(c)  If the owner states no preference, and if a tractor trailer must be towed, and if the approved wrecker service on duty for that week is not an approved heavy wrecker service, then the police officer shall request Douglas County 911 to call both the approved wrecker service on duty for that week and the approved heavy wrecker service on duty for that two-week period. 
(d)  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to prohibit the police department from providing its own impoundment facility upon city property for the purpose of storing or holding vehicles for evidence, confiscation, or any other purpose permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-151. - Requirements for approved wrecker service impound facilities. 
(a)  Each impound facility of the applying or approved wrecker service and those of the applying or approved heavy wrecker service must be located within Douglas County and within one mile of the city limits of Douglasville, Georgia, and shall be owned or leased by the applicant. 
(b)  The gate to the impound lot shall be locked and remain locked during the hours of darkness except to provide reasonable ingress and egress in connection with wrecker service operations. 
(c)  Each approved wrecker service and each approved heavy wrecker service shall submit to the police department an inventory of all vehicles remaining in its possession whose owner has not been identified and notified. The inventory shall be submitted within seven days of any request by the police department but not less frequently than every six months, and shall be completed on a form supplied or approved by the city. 
(d)  The requirements for the impound facility of any approved wrecker permit holder and any approved heavy wrecker permit holder are as follows: 
(1)  Impoundment must be located on any properly zoned location within Douglas County and one mile of the city limits of Douglasville, Georgia, and complying with all the respective city ordinances. 
(2)  Must have entire lot adequately illuminated during the hours of darkness to discourage and detect attempts at theft or vandalism. 
(3)  All fences must be of eight feet tall, opaque, and made of chain link or wood, screened, barbed wire running at the top, with gates that can be securely locked. 
(4)  An attendant for every approved wrecker service impound facility shall be available to provide service at the storage lot seven days per week between 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. within one hour of any request, whether or not the permit holder is on call for that week. Such service shall include ingress and egress for release of stored vehicles from the storage lot, and allowing the registered owner of the vehicle to retrieve personal items from the vehicle while it is impounded. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-152. - Insurance required. 
Approved wrecker services and approved heavy wrecker services shall carry liability insurance policies in compliance with the requirements of the state department of motor vehicle safety for loss or damage occasioned by negligence or misfeasance on the part of the wrecker service, and name the city as an additional insured. Such policies shall be provided to the city upon request and yearly along with the occupation tax return for the wrecker service. Such policies shall also provide for full loss, theft or damage benefits payable to any vehicle or property owner suffering loss, theft or damage with respect to any vehicle or to equipment, accessories, personal articles or other items either attached to or located within a vehicle removed and/or stored while such vehicle is in the custody, control and possession of the wrecker service. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-153. - Response of approved wrecker service. 
(a)  When any approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service arrives on the scene of an accident, the investigating officer of the police department will make a notation to be included on the impound sheet as to its time of arrival, and will make a second notation of the time the wrecker service leaves the scene with the tow in charge. This time will be considered the official time for the time charged, if any, by the wrecker service. If the wrecker service should arrive before the police unit, the officer will ascertain its time of arrival by ascertaining the time from the wrecker service driver. The officer will then be responsible for noting the time the wrecker service departs from the scene. 
(b)  Should a mistake be made in good faith by the police department or Douglas County 911 in dispatching the wrong wrecker service, no charge can be made by the wrong wrecker service for such response or the return to place of business. 
(c)  Where the investigating officer of the police department at any accident scene determines that the on-call wrecker service has failed to appear at the accident scene within 30 minutes of the request for service, the police officer shall have the option to cancel the request for service to the on-call wrecker service, and to place a request for service with the approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service which will be on-call for the subsequent week. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-154. - Daily storage charge for approved wrecker service and approved heavy wrecker service; fee for wrecker service. 
The provisions of this section apply to all work performed for any customer of an approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service when service is requested by the police department. No fees other than those authorized by this section may be charged for towing a passenger car when called upon to do so by the police department. Subsections a. through i. do not apply to towing of tractor trailers. 
(a)  No approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service shall charge in excess of $20.00 per day for storage of a passenger car in an uncovered lot; this subsection does not apply to the towing of tractor trailers. 
(b)  No approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service shall charge in excess of $25.00 per day for storage of a passenger car in a covered lot or building. 
(c)  No approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service shall charge for the first 24 hours that the vehicle was stored in any lot. 
(d)  No approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service shall charge for any day the wrecker service impound lot is closed or the owner of the vehicle is unable to claim his vehicle. 
(e)  No approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service shall store vehicles at a location other than the secure impound lot submitted for city approval without written prior approval of the police department. 
(f)  No approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service shall charge in excess of $125.00 for towing a vehicle that is undamaged from one location to another when called upon to do so by the police department. 
(g)  No approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service shall charge in excess of $175.00 for towing a damaged vehicle from one location to another when called upon to do so by the police department. 
(h)  An approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service may charge a $45.00 administrative fee whenever that service must seek the identity of and address of all known owners of the vehicle from the law enforcement or from the State of Georgia and give notice to the owners as required by O.C.G.A. section 4-11-2(a), provided however that an approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service shall not be charged this administrative fee if the owner retrieves the vehicle within twenty-four hours of the tow. 
(i)  As an exception, if the vehicle to be towed is in a rolled-over state, the approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service may charge an additional $50.00, and if specialized equipment is needed to get the vehicle on the tow truck, then the approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service may charge an additional $50.00, but this specialized equipment will be listed on the billing statement. 
(j)  Whenever any city-owned or city-leased vehicle needs to be towed, the on-call approved wrecker service or approved heavy wrecker service shall tow it without charge as long as the tow is within Douglas County, Georgia, or shall be towed for a charge of not more than $175.00 if the tow trip is wholly or partly outside Douglas County, but originates or ends at a location within 40 miles of Douglas County, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-155. - Minimum equipment. 
(a)  Each approved wrecker service under the provisions of this article shall have the following minimum equipment in operating condition: 
(1)  A roll back wrecker rated at one ton or greater; and 
(2)  Two of the following: 
a.  Roll back wrecker(s); or 
b.  Wrecker(s) rated at one ton or greater with a wheel lift and a winch rated at four tons or greater. 
(b)  Each approved heavy wrecker service shall additionally have a wrecker rated for the towing of tractor trailers. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-156. - Revocation, suspension of wrecker service operation. 
With 24 hours' notice the police chief may temporarily suspend the permit right of any approved wrecker service to respond to calls from the city for the foregoing reasons, for repeated lesser violations of this article, or for any conduct by the approved wrecker service that threatens the public safety, property or interferes with the efficient operation of the police department. The permit holder shall be entitled to hearing before the mayor and city council upon written request for a hearing by the permit holder. The permit holder shall request such a hearing within ten calendar days of notification by chief of police. The mayor and council may revoke or suspend the permit holder's right to respond to calls from the city. The permit holder shall be provided five days advance written notice of the hearing date by hand delivery or certified mail return receipt requested. The hearing before the mayor and council shall be held within 14 days of such written request by the permit holder. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
Sec. 90-157. - Penalty for violation. 
Violations of the provisions of this article shall be punishable in the municipal court as provided in article IV of the City Charter. Each day such violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-75 , § 1, 10-2-17) 
APPENDIX A - ZONING[1]
